13th November 1926

Dear Sir:

Mr. Peter Harper, teacher at the Indian Day School, Hollow Water River Reserve, has requested the Department to grant permission to repair the Anglican Mission House at an expenditure not to exceed $20.00 so that it can be made habitable for the winter.

I beg to refer you to your letter No. 125-5-5, dated 26th August, 1923, in which you authorize expenditure of $50.00 for the same purpose on this building. This work was never done and I would recommend that the authority be renewed.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

CANADA
May 20, 1927.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I am pleased to inform you that the Department has made arrangements with His Lordship the Bishop of Keewatin for qualified teaching services at the Hollow Water River Indian Day School. This activity is quite regular and the school is well attended. The Department wishes to arrange for the erection of a combined classroom and teacher's residence. I understand that there is a sawmill at Bad Throat, where the rough lumber can be secured, and good building sand may be obtained at Big Island. There is an appropriation of $3,500 for this building and I should be grateful if you would proceed without delay with its erection. Please be guided by general instructions in Dr. Scott's 1-1-5 of the 6th instant.

Yours very truly,

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 20th instant 125-5-5 with reference to the building of a proposed new combination school and teacher's residence at the Hollow Water Indian Reserve, and reply to say that if the Bishop expects to have a building of frame, with lath and plaster erected it will be pretty close figuring to do it within the amount of $3500.00. However, this matter will be looked into and the work started.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Sir,

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report in connection with schools that on my recent trip to Manitoba I made arrangements for the building of the Hollow Water School with Mr. A. G. Monkman of Selkirk. He is supplying all material, labour, etc., for the sum of $2500.00. This is $1000.00 below the amount estimated and I consider it a very low price, and as he was the lowest tenderer and bears a good reputation as a builder, there was no reason that I could see why he should not get the work.

The size of the building is 34 x 40 with two rooms at one end for the teacher's living quarters. This is along the lines requested by His Lordship, the Bishop of Keewatin.

M. Christianson
Selkirk, Man., 19th September, 1927

Sir:

When at Hollow Water River and Bloodvein Reserves in last summer the school teachers reported that some of the biscuits had been damaged in transit by water. I instructed them to open all the boxes and let me know exactly the amount spoiled and I would ask the Department to replace them. I have received the following information:

At Hollow Water out of 16 boxes shipped, 13 were spoiled and unfit for feed. At Bloodvein, out of 24 boxes, 15 were damaged. This will mean a shortage of 31 boxes or 775 lbs. to be replaced.

I should state that the damage was done between Necla and Hollow Water, and Matheson Island and Bloodvein, where the transportation has to be made in small boats.

Willingly let me have your decision regarding this at an early date and oblige,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, September 22nd., 1927.

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 19th instant, I beg to state that 775 lbs. biscuits have been ordered from The Canada Biscuit Company, of Winnipeg, for the Hollow Water River and Bloodvein Day Schools. These biscuits will be shipped to your address at Selkirk.

Yours truly,

F.H. Paget
Chief Accountant and Purchasing Agent.

C.A. Stevenson Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Selkirk, Man.

CANADA
Ottawa, June 18, 1928.

Very Rev. Sir:

The Department has received a communication from His Lordship the Bishop of Kewatin in which he states that Rev. E. W. Gardner, teacher of the Hollow Water River Indian Day School, is giving up duties, and nominates Mr. Cathcart, who holds an Ontario Second Class Certificate, for the position to succeed Mr. Gardner. The Department will approve of the appointment of Mr. Cathcart, with salary at the rate of $75 per teaching month. If he dispenses medicines, he will receive an annual grant of $50 for this service. It is presumed that Mr. Cathcart will begin his duties as teacher at the beginning of the next school year, or about September 4th, next. We are informing Mr. Agent Stevenson of the appointment of Mr. Cathcart.

His Lordship requests that, owing to there being insufficient accommodation in the teacher's residence in connection with the new school building for Mr. Cathcart and his family, the Church authorities be allowed the use of the old school building, which they propose to fit up at the expense of the Church. He states that by using the two rooms of the school residence, with cellar and the three rooms, into which it is proposed to divide the old building, ample accommodation will be provided. The Department has no objection to the Church authorities fitting up and using the old school building for the purpose mentioned.

His Lordship requested that owing to his absence we inform you of the above matters.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ven. Archdeacon J. Lofthouse,
Kenora,
Ont.

Selkirk, Man. 25th September, 1928

Sir:

I beg to enclose requisition for school material received from Mr. E.W. Cathcart, the new teacher at Hollow Water Indian Reserve.

There is one sheet marked "Special Requisition" which includes today's request for visitors' chair and number of desks. In his letter he states that there is at present seating accommodation for 13 pupils, and as there are 25 pupils attending, there will not be sufficient seats. I beg to inform you that there are 25 children on the school register, but the average attendance for the last term is 11.75. These figures are taken from the quarterly returns ending Dec. 15th and March 15th, 1928.

When this school was built in 1927, the toilets were omitted and these are urgently needed.

He also suggests building a fence round the school so as to keep cattle and horses from the building. This I consider necessary but can be delayed until next spring as it is getting too late to do this work now.

I enclose Mr. Cathcart's letter which kindly return for this office files.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.
The Department is not prepared to supply the extinguishers, sanitary drinking cups and holders.

We are sending a 6' flag to the teacher.

Relative to the fencing, this will have to stand over until next spring. You should, at that time, again draw the attention of the Department to the matter, giving full particulars as to the amount of fencing required, the type and cost of same.

Relative to the toilets, I shall be pleased if you will furnish an estimate of the cost of the erection of separate toilets - one for the boys and one for the girls. They should be of an inexpensive type. When we have this information, consideration will then be given to authorizing the erection of same.

It is considered that, with the number of desks which you are authorized to purchase, there should be sufficient seating accommodation for the number of children who will attend, and we are, therefore, not prepared at the present time to supply the number of single desks which the teacher requested.

I am returning herewith the communication which you received from the teacher relative to his requisitions.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

[Signature]

Ottawa, October 26th, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant, giving an estimate of the cost of erecting toilets at the Hollow Water River Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the department will approve of having this work carried out. We note that you estimate the cost to be approximately $37.20 and that the work can be done by an Indian of the band. You should arrange for the purchase and forwarding of the material required. These toilets should be erected on a suitable site.

When the work is completed, please forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the material and for the labour. The total expenditure should not exceed if possible your estimate.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

I beg to enclose requisition for material for renovating and re-painting Hollow Water School, which has been received from Mr. Cathcart, the teacher.

The outside toilets were built last fall, and have never been painted.

The walls and ceiling of the school house are finished with beaverboard and are badly smoked and blackened. Mr. Cathcart offers to do this work himself gratis, and would try and have the work done by the time that treaty payments are made, on 5th June.

On 25th September last I wrote about fencing the school grounds and in your reply No.125-5-5, of 1st Oct., you recommended that this matter stand over until the spring and then bring it before the Department. Mr. Cathcart reports that the Indians have supplied and delivered the posts on the ground and will also drive them and build the fence free. The only cost to the Department would be for barbed wire, staples. This fence is badly needed as the school is built on an open point, which is the pasture for all the horses and cattle on the reserve.

Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your Voucher No. 644/31, for $3.85, in favour of Moody's, Ltd., in connection with the night classes conducted for the Indians at the Hollowwater River Indian Day School.

Sir:

Replying to your letter No. 123-5-5 of 24th instant, referring to Voucher No. 644-31 for $3.85 in favour of Moody's Ltd., in connection with night classes at Hollow Water River Reserve, I beg to advise you that the teacher, Mr. Rob Marsh, wrote on 14th October, requesting the Department to supply gasoline and mantles for a lamp so that he could continue holding night school for the Band. He had already started these classes, supplying the gasoline himself.

As a boat was leaving for Hollow Water with Relief supplies that day, which was expected, and in fact proved to be the last trip of the season, I considered it advisable to forward this, more especially as the previous teachers had received this supply so as to carry on the work.

Mr. Marsh holds these classes four nights a week and reports good attendance.

I trust this explanation will be acceptable to the Department.

Our obedient servant,

Selkirk, Man., April 28, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing herewith our requisition for paint for the Hollow Water Indian Day School, as per our Estimates for 1941-42.

Mr. Marsh, the school teacher, has again requested that paint be supplied for his school this year and advises that if the Department will supply the paint and materials, there will be no charge for the labour of putting the paint on.

In view of the fact that this school has not been painted for many years and that it is badly in need of paint both inside and out, I would recommend that the Department approve of this requisition.

Trusting that the Department will favourably consider this request, I am,

Very truly yours,

E. McPherson,
Indian Agent.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Re: Teacher for Hole River,
our letter of 14th inst.

Thank you for your letter of the 19th inst. with reference to Mr. Emil Plancknert.

I am sorry your Department is not able to approve his appointment as permit teacher at Hole River. Since the end of September last we have endeavored by all possible means to secure a certified teacher for the school. With the great shortage of teachers, and with many teaching on permit in Manitoba, there is little hope of our securing a certified teacher. The people are most anxious to have a missionary-teacher, and I had hoped that with his wide experience Mr. Plancknert would be acceptable to the Department. He is well educated and speaks four European languages and has had some experience in Manitoba. He was formerly a monk in the Roman Catholic Church in Belgium, and by conviction he left that Church and was later connected with our Church in Ireland.

If it is possible to give further consideration to our recommendation in view of the extreme difficulty of securing a teacher for the school at Hole River, I should be much obliged, for I am of the opinion that the above-named would do good work.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Indians Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Resources,

Please find attached, requisition for School Supplies, for Hollow Water Reserve Day School. As you will note, there is a new school teacher just appointed, Mr. E. Planckaert. There has been no school teacher at this reserve since Mr. Marsh died a year ago.

There are 47 pupils at this school, with desk accommodation for 32. The remainder must either sit on the floor or boxes. This situation makes it extremely difficult for the young children to carry on with their lessons and studies.

The weather indicates an early freeze up, so may this matter be taken care of immediately.

E. McPherson, Indian Agent.

Sir,

The Methodist work at Island Lake has been carried on with vigor for the last four years but the greatest progress has been made in the three years last past. A Parsonage was commenced and completed in 1908. A Church has been built this year and is approaching completion. A school was organized by the Rev Mr Cunningham and was taught by his daughter in 1908 and this year is being taught by himself and his wife. This School was recognized by the Department under the number quoted above, dated October 8th 09, and the grant dates by that authority from July 1st of the current year. It is practically a boarding school as the clergyman has found that to get anything regular in attendance he has had to get the children to stay with him. This as was explained in a former letter of mine arises from the fact that the Parents being all hunters are scattered over a large area making it impossible for children to reach the School. The lake is stormy and the way is long.

School has been kept in the Ministers house but is to be moved to the Church building as soon as it is ready.

The population of Island Lake is shown by the Treaty given last summer to have been 580. The juvenile element was made up of 176 boys and 154 girls. All these are of the most illiterate type, the most uncivilized people I have yet met. The need of Schooling is therefore quite apparent. A school building is quite necessary.

Missionaries Going to Northern Manitoba

The Rev. H. L. Chappell and his bride have been appointed to mission work among the Cree Indians in Northern Manitoba. The career of Mr. Chappell includes the full course in arts and divinity at Saint John's College, Halifax; his education being placed this year along with Mr. Biecn and others at the Maritime Conference of The United Church. Mrs. Chappell was formerly Miss Mary Mosher, of Sussex, N.B., and holds the first-class certificate of the province of New Brunswick. Mr. Chappell is a native of Westmount North in Cape Breton county. He first served the Home Mission Board on the Red Bank, and in Miramichi Presbytery in 1927. The next year he was at Salton, in St. John Presbytery, and was invited to return there for 1929. In 1930 he received commendation for services rendered at Bevitt, in Moose Jaw Presbytery. He studied homiletics in Greek at Mount Allison University, and in New Testament at Pine Hill Divinity Hall on graduation this year.

The Chappells will spend their first year of married life on the Island Lake field. The mission house is nine days' overland from Norway House, or nine "sleeps" as the Indians call the shorter distance while canoeing and portaging between camps. In the winter they will take three hundred mile trips by dog train to the five main camps to which the Indian trappers and their families scatter for the fur season. The Indians come back to the permanent camps only in the spring and summer: at Wasagamaw, Marle Portage and Island Lake, and at that time the best opportunity for pastoral and school work presents itself. For the school, Miss Frances MacKenzie, late of Calgary, and formerly associated with Dr. Grenfell's work in Labrador, remains at Island Lake with the Chappells to conduct the school. When she goes they will be in full charge of the mission.
I think these are the outstanding facts, and now I leave it to you to judge, whether or not the experiment has been a success, and is worth doing every summer.

Yours truly,

I am in quandry, with regard to my report on the Summer School. I hardly feel able to judge as to its success etc., so I will state the facts as nearly as possible, and leave the decision to someone else.

A large registration was obtained, quite early in the session, being sixty-seven in all. The regularity of attendance, and interest in general, was fairly good until Treaty time. Treaty being paid at Maria Portage, on the other reserve this year, took the entire population away from here for about eight days. Those pupils who attended with a fair amount of regularity have progressed to the stage, where, if they were to attend from now on they would advance steadily, that is they are emerging from the initiation period.

Re Mrs. Chappell's Appointment to Island Lake.

I have not yet written to Mrs. Chappell because I am not entirely satisfied that the months of October and November are the best months for holidays at Island Lake from the standpoint of the Indian.

Letters to and from Island Lake are necessarily very slow, but I take the liberty of quoting a paragraph from the latest letter received from the present teacher, Miss Frances Patterson, in response to an enquiry made by me on March 8th. She expects that the summer session will end this year - as it did last year - at the end of August.

"Re the question of closing the school for the months of October and November. I have discussed the problem with the Chappells from every angle, and we have come to the conclusion that the months of April and May would be the best in which to close the school. It is quite true that the people take their families away during fishing season in October and November, but they also do this during the muskrat season in April and May. From the teacher's standpoint we decided in favor of the spring months, because dog team travelling in the latter part of March or the beginning of April would be more agreeable than in November or December. Also, April and May are pleasanter months in which to take a holiday. Again, the teacher who came in, in May, fresh from a holiday would be in trim for the heaviest portion of the teaching year, - the summer session."

I should be glad to know what your reaction to Miss Patterson's suggestion is, that the holiday months should be April and May rather than October and November. Of course, I can see a disadvantage from the standpoint of the Department during their present fiscal year in following her suggestion, as it would mean twelve months' teaching this year at Island Lake, as it did a year ago. It will be rather difficult, however, if Miss Patterson leaves the end of August and the school is open only one month and then closed for October and November. I think there is probably still time to communicate with Mr. Gordon at Norway House and get his opinion on the matter before Mrs. Chappell begins her work.

Dear Sir:

Re: Island Lake Indian Day School.

With further reference to the appointment of Mrs. H. L. Chappell as teacher at the Indian Day School, Island Lake, Manitoba, may I say that so far as I know the contention in your letter of August 19th is based on a misapprehension of the whole situation.

The decision to establish a summer school at Island Lake was arrived at following a conference which I had with Mr. Russell Nervier after I had personally spent ten days on the ground in 1930. The keeping of the school open during July and August was in the nature of an experiment and was to be covered by a special grant of $200.00 for two successive summers. The pupils were to be children not enrolled in the regular day school during the ordinary academic year. It was felt that both at Gods' Lake and at Island Lake the experience of a summer school should be tried out for two years in order to determine whether or not it was possible in this way to make a real contribution to the life of these bush Indians. We have therefore from the beginning never considered that the keeping of the school open during July and August had any reference to the normal number of teaching months or teaching days for which the Department assumes responsibility for an Indian day school. The $200.00 for 1931 and 1932 was regarded as being in the nature of a grant. Whether this grant should be continued for 1933 or not is a matter on which for the present I have no very settled convictions. I have not yet received a copy of Miss Patterson's report for this summer, and I am also waiting to hear from Mr. Indian Agent Gordon as to his opinion of the whole matter after his recent visit to Island Lake for the payment of Treaty.

I cannot agree to the interpretation in your letter of August 19th, that it is impossible for Mrs. Chappell to begin teaching the regular day school on the 1st September because there has been a special grant for carrying on a summer school during July and August and the auditors may object.

I trust that this explanation may be satisfactory to you and that Miss Patterson's special cheque for her work during July and August, 1932, may come forward in due course as in the case of the grant for 1931.

Yours sincerely,

When on their way back to Winnipeg from the Maritimes, it was discovered that Mrs. Chappell had something the matter with her ear and the specialist strongly advised against her going in where there was no doctor. He and Mr. Chappell went in from Norway House by plane, which today is considerably cheaper than the former method of travel by canoe. Sir,

I beg to advise you that last summer at treaty time, both Father Maclean of the Roman Catholic Mission and Mr. Gavin H. Grieve of the United Church Mission on the Island Lake Reserve, spoke about what they regarded as the necessity of establishing another Indian Day School on that reserve, to accommodate approximately 30 Indian children, at Wasagamach, which is from seven to 12 miles from any school on the reserve, and consequently are getting nothing in the way of education. The matter was just talked about, without any definite action being taken.

I have, since that time, received requests from both the R.C. Mission, and the United Church Mission, to take the matter up with the Department, with a view to having this school established. Father Maclean of the R.C. Mission enclosed with his letter a petition (in the Cree syllabics), signed by the Chief and Councillors of the Island Lake Band, requesting that the Department would establish this school. Mr. Gavin H. Grieve, the United Church Missionary, advises me that the parents of the children in question have assured him that they will co-operate with that church to the best of their ability, and that they urge our building school if one is established. Mr. Grieve also states that the United Church erected a building at Wasagamach last year, which would be very suitable for a day school.

How many of the thirty children, or their parents, are affiliated with each church, I do not know, but it is evident that both missionaries are concerned about the same thirty children. If a school were opened under the auspices of either church, the children affiliated with the other, would doubtless not attend. Would an un-denominational school, operated solely by the Department, answer the problem? The school, if established, would have to be a summer school, carrying only during the months of June, July, and August. Apart from an un-denominational school, the only alternatives would be to open two schools, one under the auspices of each church, or no school at all.

I should be glad if you would advise me what the Department considers might be done in this matter, if anything.

Your obedient Servant,

The Island Lake Indians are very primitive; far more so than the Indians outside on the prairies; and they seldom come in contact with white people, apart from the traders. Scholastic education is of far less importance to them than it is to the prairie Indian, and I am of the opinion that if these Indians receive sufficient schooling to enable them to speak fairly good English, and write fairly decently; and figure and know the value of money, they do not really require much else. Moreover; if the children are kept on the reserve by their parents during the winter months, instead of being taken out to the prairies to be set at trap, they are not going to be able to earn a living for themselves when they grow up past school age, and that is a matter of the utmost importance. Hunting, trapping, and fishing are the sole means of livelihood for these Indians, and the parents are the children's only teachers so far as these occupations are concerned.

Frankly speaking; rather than try to increase the school attendance during the winter months, I would favour making both these schools 'seasonal' schools, and operate them for the four months from June to September inclusive only, leaving them closed for the balance of the year. The average attendance at these schools during the six months period September to March does not seem to justify the paying of two teachers $90.00 a month each for that period, and to increase the attendance would mean that a greater number of families would have to remain on the reserve during the winter instead of getting out to the prairies to earn their living, and that is not desirable, as the inevitable result would be that they would become dependent upon the Department instead of themselves for their living.

These two schools are now having their annual vacation; during the two months April and May; and I should be pleased to have your opinion on the foregoing.

Your obedient Servant,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No; 123-4-l of the 6th instant, having reference to the low average attendance during the December and March quarters, at the Island Lake United Church Indian Day School.

In reply, I beg to say that I am unable to state the reason for the attendance becoming so low during these two quarters, from personal inspections of the school. This reserve, (as well as God's Lake and Oxford House), is never visited except at treaty time, owing to its isolation, distance, and travel difficulties and cost of getting there from Norway House. At treaty time of course the schools are not in session, and they are consequently never inspected.

However, from reports that have come to me at various times, and from various sources, during the time I have been Agent here, it appears that the Indians who live near the neighbourhood of the United Church School, are practically all away from the reserve to their winter trapping camps about the 15th September, where they stay all winter, returning to the reserve about the following June. When they leave, they take their wives and children with them of course, and in consequence, the school attendance suffers. In the case of those Indians who live in proximity to the R.C.Mission, it is very adverse and is a very large measure. Far too many of them prefer to stay around the reserve, instead of getting away to the bush to hunt and trap as they should do, and earn their living. Several families do go of course, but the greater number stay and their children are available for school attendance, consequently the average attendance at the R.C.School does not fall so low as at the U.C.School during the winter months.

Of course this was not the case. Mr. Grafton and myself are only interested in trying to get adequate schools for our people. I have had an architect draw plans for the set up which we think would be a great advance over the present residential type of school. And it will be necessary for any type of residence to be provided for the Island Lake children if they are to get a school for more than a few weeks each year. The people have one way to make a living and that is off the country and have to go far afield in the winter to the trapping grounds so the children cannot attend any school except for a very few. Our present day school is all that is necessary if only day schools are contemplated as summer schools are not worth bothering with.

I cannot understand why something definite was not submitted for your perusal by our H. M. Board. We were actually expecting to get started on the job last January, had timber cruised a small amount for and an agreement had been made for a list of materials to the last nail. We were ready to go ahead and thought that by next September we would have at least 100 of our children in school. Until your letter arrived this week I was totally ignorant about the fact that nothing whatever had been proposed by the H. M. Board. I can hardly credit it yet.

Of course I put the blame on Mr. Hoey and thought he was giving us the run around. Dear Mr. Crerar:

I wish to thank you for your letter of April 28th which got in here this week. For the time you took from your many duties and the information so clearly set out therein.

I think that an explanation is due both you and Mr. Hoey for what must have looked like an unwarrantable outbreak on my part and also a lack of diligence and co-operation on the part of Mr. Grafton. I will try to set out the circumstances in order of occurrence and you will readily see that both Mr. Grafton and myself were misled about proposed developments in respect to schools for our people.

For the past five years we have pleaded with our Home Mission Board through the officials with whom we work for something to be done about schools for our people. Last summer on the visit of Dr. John A. Cormie, our superintendent, we went into the whole picture, giving every conceivable detail in connection with the need and the desire for an improvement plan to come with it. This all in writing. We were given to understand that this plan was to be submitted to you and were assured that we would be given the result of the conference with you as to what would be done. Our Indians were assured that this would be presented to your Department in as strong a manner as possible. At different times we have received letters in reply from the Superintendent, Dr. Cormie, that he had not had word yet, the last coming at the time of Mr. Hoey's letter to Mr. Grafton. From your letter it is clear that nothing whatever in the shape of a plan was submitted by anybody in our Church except a few snap shots. Mr. Grafton at once replied to Mr. Hoey's letter which in the face of our assurance that the same had worked out and been submitted, was quite an adequate reply to the letter but in reality with nothing whatever submitted by the Home Mission Board was of course unsatisfactory. Due to our poor mail service it was not for weeks that Mr. Grafton's letter got to Mr. Hoey and in the meantime Mr. Hoey had suggested that Mr. Grafton be asked to resign and Mr. Hoey wrote a letter to the House of Parliament that it was likely due to his influence that Mr. Grafton had evaded giving the information asked for.

Dear Sirs:

Re - Island Lake Day School

A couple of days ago I received a notice from your Department to the effect that the day schools on Indian Reserves would not open until October, and that henceforth they would be operated for a nine months' period each year - the teachers to receive nine months' salary rather than ten. Now, I have a letter before me from Dr. Comrie, our Superintendent of Missions in Manitoba, in reference to the Island Lake School. He has passed on to us the name of a young man whom he has recommended as teacher of this school. The Island Lake School, as you know, begins in June and has continued for ten months, with a salary of $1000.00 a year. Now you know that the expenses in the North, and to and from the North, are higher than in other places. What I want to know is, does your Department intend to have the new regulation affect such a place as Island Lake? Can we not expect a salary of $1000.00 for this school, even though the period of teaching may be only nine months?

If the salary is to be reduced by $100 for such a school as Island Lake, we may find considerable difficulty in getting qualified teachers to go in at all. If there is to be this reduction in Island Lake, we must let the young man whom we propose to nominate know, so that there will be no misunderstanding about the matter. I hope that the new rule will not apply to this school.

Of course, what I have to say about Island Lake School applies to such schools as Garford House, Nelson House, Cross Lake, Little Grand Rapids, Berens River, and any others in this class.

I shall be glad to hear from you at the earliest possible moment in regard to this matter.

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

CHIEF HENRY FIDDLER,
#177 Island Lake Band.

538 Dominion Public Bldg.,

August 19th, 1943.

As I have come so far from the North and spent quite a few dollars to reach Winnipeg to find out the truth, I would desire consideration of my please. I am coming to find out where my headquarters are and concerning our treaty. I ask the opportunity to put my grievances before the headquarters of the Indian Department for my band of Indians and their rights. My Council has given me their authority to present any grievance that we have for our band.

My people have no education. We have about three hundred children at present fit for school but no school to take them in. We have two small schools, one on each side of the lake, Roman Catholic and Protestant, but these are too small for the present population of school-age children. We would very much appreciate a boarding school instead of the day schools, and the children from our neighbouring reserves, God's Lake and Oxford House, could also attend. All the Indians from these Reserves could benefit by a boarding school, as well as by a hospital.

I very much appreciate this opportunity to lay our grievances before the Department and will be very thankful if the Department can give consideration to our requests.
Norway House, Man.

I wish to submit the following report on the schools of the Norway House Agency, inspected in June, 1945.

Island Lake U.C. Indian Day School

The teacher, Miss E. Loewen, had left before I arrived. The roll showed 42 - three in grade 2 and the balance in grade 1.

This is a log school. Some repair is needed to the roof and the floor needs painting. The material is on hand, I understand, and the work will be carried out during the summer.

If we had a school residence I would recommend that a married couple be engaged and that they do social and welfare work, as well as teach. They should be hired by the year with, say, a month's holidays. They could then supervise a good garden and help in the organization of social groups. The woman could instruct and help the Indian women in the sewing clubs and social organizations. A married couple interested in the work would be a great help to the Agent and could do very excellent work. There are about 160 United Church children of school age. If these are to be accommodated in day schools we would need three more schools. These Indians are trappers and I doubt if day schools can even be considered as an answer to the great need. The parents cannot remain on the reserve in the winter and trap, and the children cannot be away with their parents and attend a day school; consequently there appears only one solution and that is more boarding schools.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

REPORT OF TOUR OF NORWAY HOUSE AGENCY BY AIR JANUARY 7th TO JANUARY 13th, 1946.

XX XX XX

JAN 9 Inspected U.C. Day School at Garden Hill, Island Lake; 28 pupils present. Mr. Rempel, the teacher is not a qualified teacher and gave me the impression that he didn't quite know what it was all about. I gave him what advice and help I could. The school building is of log construction with a low ceiling and no ventilation. It is 17' x 27' and there is no porch. There are enough children in this settlement to fill 3 day schools. There are no Teacherages for any of the schools in this Agency. The children, wherever I went were well-fed and well-clothed. I gave a half holiday in order that I could use the building for a Band Meeting. The meeting assured me that the people were doing their best to see that the Family Allowance money was spent in accordance with the regulations laid down. Here again we discussed the 5 year building and improvement plan, and general satisfaction was registered. They asked about their Saw Mill and I assured them that our engineer Mr. Stevenson would install it for them as early as possible in the spring. I am doubtful of the success of this venture unless an experienced man is placed in charge. I have already recommended that such an appointment be made by the Dept., i.e. a married couple, the man to act as overseer and his wife as Field Matron. I advised the Indians to start getting their logs ready.

A request was made by the meeting for a grant of $40.00 to repair a foot bridge and its approaches to enable children to attend school.

In the afternoon I visited several homes in company with Dr. Corrigan and Father Dutil. Several Indians need medical attention.

XX XX XX

S.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

MR. T. H. L. MacINNES,
Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch.

Reference your 470-2-3 of June 30 -

We are conducting two day schools on the Island Lake Reserve,-

(1) Maria Portage
Last winter we conducted a three-room school at Maria Portage and had an attendance of some 90 children.

We employed 3 lay teachers and I understand that everyone was pleased with the results of their efforts. Next winter we will have three qualified teachers from an Order of teaching Sisters. We have just completed arrangements for taking over a trader's store at Island Lake which can be converted for use as an additional classroom.

(2) Garden Hill
Here we have operated a one-room United Church Day School. We have had a teacher there for some years now but were unable to get one for the last academic year (1947-48). However, we are now building a new school with attached teacherage at Island Lake and we feel that we will be in a position to interest a teacher in view of the better accommodation being offered.

However, we would point out that it is becoming increasingly difficult to interest teachers in going to isolated Indian reserves, particularly where there are no facilities for entertainment and social contacts.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Dr Best:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 9th 1948 and your inquiry regarding the situation at Island Lake in connection with the U.C. Indian Day School.

The Department is building a combined Day School & Teacherage at Island Lake but this building will not be complete until approximately 15 November, and at this time it would be impossible to transport a Teacher to Island Lake with the result that school would not open at Island Lake until 1st January 1948.

The old Island Lake U.C. Indian Day School which is located on the Treaty Grounds at Garden Hill is in good condition and at the present time is fully equipped. With the object of opening the old school until such time as the new School & Teacherage is complete, I telegraphed Mr Austin Hodgkinson at Island Lake this past week asking if he were in a position to board & lodge a teacher until 15th November and below give reply which was received this morning:

RETEL WILL BE IN POSITION TO BOARD AND LODGE TEACHER
STOP AUSTIN NOT HOME BUT BELIEVE SATISFACTORY RATE CAN
BE ARRANGED - SIGNED MRS HODGKINSON

I should state that Austin Hodgkinson is quite close to the old Day School and is the only one at Island Lake in a position to supply board & lodging.
If Miss Clinton accepts position as teacher to commence duties 1st September in the Old School, she would have sufficient time after she arrives at Island Lake to make her own arrangements concerning provisions for the balance of the term. She could either have her supplies flown in before freeze-up or they could come in by tractor freight in the month of January.

Yours very truly,

Q.P. Jackson,
Agency Clerk.
Mr E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agency, Norway House, Manitoba

Dear Mr Goodman:

I am sorry to know that you have not been well. I hope that you will have a speedy and complete recovery.

I am anxious to know the situation regarding the school at Island Lake. My information is that a new school including teacher's living quarters, is being built. Can you tell me when it will be ready and when it will be furnished? Miss Joyce Clinton of St. James, Man., is making an application for this school. She is 20 years old, has Grade XI standing but no professional training. She has taught in the Anglican Residential School at Sioux Lookout. I have had an interview with her and believe that she would prove satisfactory. Of course, I would very much prefer to nominate a fully qualified teacher and until two weeks ago had one in view, but she has withdrawn her application. It is still very difficult to find qualified teachers for Indian Schools and I am told that many schools throughout the province will have to employ permit teachers again this year.

In the event of the new school and living quarters not being ready for the 1st of September could the term begin in the old school? And have you any suggestion as to where Miss Clinton could live in the meantime? Will it be necessary for the teacher to take in her own provisions for the year and if so how should they be shipped?

I will hold Miss Clinton's application until I hear from you.

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) C.H. Best.
Norway House, Manitoba

Dear Sir:

Copy of your letter of Aug. 13th to Mr. Frank M. Hughes of the Norway House Agency reached this office while Dr. Best was away on a short vacation. I have been able to communicate with him and he tells me that he is not able to recommend Miss Joyce Clinton for the Island Lake Indian Day School. He wrote Miss Clinton in July telling her that he could not nominate her for this position. Island Lake is fairly isolated and it did not seem right to send a young girl there unless she was in the best of health. We have had her application form on file for sometime.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6236, file 516-3, part 1)
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st ultimo re the return of the Island Lake School, and beg to say that communications between here and Island Lake are of the most precarious nature and it takes many months to get in touch with these regions. This is about the only excuse I can give for the late arrival of the returns. Revd. John McDougall was advised that the grant would be available as early as the 16th of June 1902 and the school work could hardly start before October of that year. The returns, so far as I know, have been made bona fide and the attendance is better than at most of the Day Schools. I hope this will satisfy the Auditor General. I will write to the Teacher to send his returns in future, if possible, at the end of every quarter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Commissioner.

Secretary,
Dept. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have the honor to enclose herewith the Return of Island Lake Day School for the Quarter ended Sept. 30th last. The number of School days in Quarter are counted only from August 1st, as the school was opened on that date.

Though the average was small, it was fair for a beginning, since there has been no school for some years. Whether the school will be a success for some time remains to be seen. The people are divided into three groups and in each almost the whole population goes trapping. The locations of the groups are also quite a distance apart. There has been considerable discussion among the groups as to the possibility of a permanent location for the whole number together, but as yet no conclusion has been arrived at.

I have the honor to enclose herewith the Quarterly Return of the Island Lake Day School for the Quarter ended December 31st, 1922.

The attendance of over ten of an average is a pleasing surprise to me, since I knew that Island Lake Indians almost invariably take their whole families with them to the trapping grounds. This was true of the families near the Mission, where the school was located. The teacher, Miss Sturdy moved over to another Village, where a building was placed at her disposal, repairs and alterations being made by the Indians, so that she was fairly comfortable, and where the Report shows she had 12 pupils, who attended the balance of the term very regularly. Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your favour of the first instant concerning the School Returns for the Island Lake Indian Day School in connection with which the Department is paying only one half month's salary for the September quarter.

The circumstances connected with Miss Frances Patterson's appointment to the Island Lake School are these: Mr. James Hart and his wife were appointed as missionaries, and Miss Patterson expected to have gone in with them. Mr. Hart's plans were suddenly changed as his wife had a stroke. Miss Patterson felt that it was her duty to proceed both in the interests of the Government and of the Church, but as she had planned to live with Mr. and Mrs. Hart she was now obliged to purchase an outfit of household necessities for her own use and to send to Winnipeg for it so as to take it along with her. She was at Norway House at the time. The delay thus occasioned prevented her from reaching Island Lake until the middle of September. It was no fault of hers or ours that she was not there to open the School at the beginning of the month. I feel quite sure she did her utmost to reach there in time.

Under the circumstances if the Department felt like paying the salary for the full month of September, we shall feel obliged as our arrangement with her calls for payment of her salary from September 1st.

Yours very sincerely,

Please let me know as soon as possible if this school will be open during the months of July and August. If so, you should state when the regular two months' holidays will be taken.

Sir:

Referring to your letter No. 123-4-3 of July 10, in which you ask me to state whether Island Lake United Church Day School would be open during the months of July and August, I would say that it was.

As to the regular two months holidays, I cannot say when these will be taken, as they will probably cover some time in November when the Indians are out fishing and possibly again in the spring after the rut season. It may also be that very few of the children will be in attendance at this school during the winter months, as practically all of the people from this point go trapping during the winter season.

We may find, if enough men are engaged for the winter at the Island Lake Mines, that it may be advisable to transfer the school to the Mines for a few months if suitable accommodations can be secured for a class room. This, however, is a matter which will have to be dealt with later as conditions arise.

In reply, I beg to say that after making a number of enquiries, it would appear that the most appropriate time for the pupils of this school to take their two months holidays would be the months of April and May each year, as at that time, the Indians are out trapping muskrats and usually wish to take their families to their camps. It is also the time of year when the spring break-up begins, making travel more or less difficult.

I would therefore recommend that the teacher be paid salary in full to date, and that salary be deducted for next April and May when the school should be closed.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G. Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Sir,

Miss Cunningham, the school teacher at Island Lake who has opened up a new day school at Island Lake last fall, is requesting that she be allowed to purchase from the H.B. Company's store at Island Lake some necessary articles for the school. As this school has only been in operation since November, and as no information had been supplied by the Methodist Mission to this office last summer that a day school would be opened at Island Lake Xkim last year, it is therefore in need of a good many things necessary to a school. I am sending a small list of the articles required for the present.

I had a letter from Miss Cunningham the school teacher in regard to the housing and feeding of 5 or 6 pupils, who are children of widows living around the Mission, this seems to me a very laudable effort on the part of Miss Cunningham to undertake this extra work, and I think that if Miss Cunningham really intends to remain for a long time at Island Lake, why not let her school be a sort of semi boarding school, then the Department would I think grant her a certain amount of provisions and clothing for these pupils next year.

Miss Cunningham mentions that she could take care of 5 or 6 pupils in this way or if assisted by the Department possibly a few more. She also states that as some of the children who live quite a distance from the school, that she would like to give them a warm meal at dinner time and that this would encourage those who live at a distance to come to the school. I respectfully submit this for your careful consideration.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In letter No. 22847/5, dated Feb. 2nd, I feel that it is a step in the right direction in allowing day schools such as Island Lake a mid-day meal for the children. On my visits to some reserves this winter, this same appeal was made by the Revd Mr Gaudin for the Cross Lake day school and also by the Revd Mr Nutty at Nelson House, whose reserve is also under the Revd Mr Gaudin's supervision.

Would the Department be kind enough to authorize the purchase of plates, cups, saucers, dessert spoons, towels, etc., for dish cloths, large dish pans, cooking pots, table salt, and oil etc., for the use of day schools on any reserve in this Agency that would require this additional help to their day schools.

I would recommend that this be done so as to enable children coming from a distance to attend school more regularly. Many of the children who went some to school now on account of the distance and the small allowance of biscuits for their mid-day meal, would probably feel more like attending the school, knowing that they would be assured of a good hot meal in the middle of the day and they would feel contented and happy, and more eager to learn.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Will you please allow me to call your attention to the fact that a teacher for the day school at this point is on the ground, but on account of the migratory habits of these Indians, it is almost impossible to keep up an average. The Indians have a number of homes at what is called the Big Village, about 15 miles from here, and would willingly send their children to the Day School if there were some way of doing it there. They are quite generally disposed toward the education of their children, as can be seen by the readiness to obey Mr. Agostino's instructions regarding School work, all of which was promptly and faithfully done.

My object in writing you this letter must be well appreciated. In the same manner as the Indian Dept. would be willing to supply said 12 days of Board, 100 lbs. tea, 100 lbs. sugar, 20 lbs. tobacco, etc., and 100 lbs. flour, I am prepared to get some charity of clothing from the Women's Missionary Society of the Methodist Church, and request an old school house near to be used for the children, and such items as the success of this school may be willing to supply a bed and tableware to assist them in making up a goodly started average. If successful we would be more than pleased to still have the Indian women do the advance work of earliest opportunity of this matter.

Yours very respectfully,

In mild weather, the church could be used, but to keep this warm in severe weather would be almost impossible. There was an old house just behind the school, of which the walls and a pole roof only remained. This was the property of an Indian of Oxford House. I told the Missionary that if it could be secured, I thought it likely that the Department would meet a small expense in making it fit for use for the purpose of the school. Mr. Chapin secured the house, and Mr. Gordon, as above, secured the slate, or used some he had on hand, and other material from his own supply, has put these in at cost, and he and the teacher have done considerable work free of charge. The school children also assisted, in gathering moss, etc., for the walls, as described to us by the teacher, the building is now fairly comfortable for the purpose intended. The attendance at this school up to October, warrants the expenditure. Later, if the building should not be required as a classroom, it can be utilized as a store room, for which purpose I understand the amount of $50. was allowed in the Estimates of 1925-26.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, requesting an advance of $500 to pay the cost of freighting building material to Island Lake to be used in the construction of a new day school building to be conducted under the auspices of the United Church at that point.

In this connection I have to say that our appropriation for the balance of the present fiscal year is entirely assigned, but when the appropriation for the next fiscal year is available, early in April next, the advance asked for will be sent you. In the meantime, it is thought you could arrange for the freighting of the material, payment for same to be made when you receive the advance.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Sir:

I have the honor to enclose Voucher No. 39, in favor of Rev. R.T. Chapin, now of Norway House, for goods supplied at Island Lake to Indians in payment for labor in the building of the United Church Day School at that point.

Mr. Chapin, as missionary at Island Lake, had a large supply of food stuffs on hand which he was using for payment in the building of a church and mission house. The Indians were paid at the rate of $3.00 per day on the school work, and the goods supplied at as nearly cost as can be computed. In this way the laborers received from 20 to 25% more for their work than if paid with orders on the stores, and considerably more than if paid with cash, as the cash would be taken up at Island Lake at higher prices for the goods.

The getting of the logs, peeling same, and getting them on the site, was considerable work. Sand and stone also had to be brought in canoes, and then carried a couple of hundred yards from the shore. Joists, both for floor and ceiling, had to be hewn, also rafters, planks, and all division stuff for the school, and lumber also had to be shipped. The grounds were covered with a heavy growth of small poplar and spruce, which had to be cleared away for a playground, and to afford some protection from fire. Moss for chinking had to be gathered and dried.

I have not seen the building since finished, but I saw it at Treaty time when the walls were up. It is certainly a fine building as all logs, and other material is of the best, and the whole building, from stone foundation, and stone chimney, walls, windows, roof, interior lining with lath, etc., and with double floor, the finishing one of maple, was well done. It should make a satisfactory building for many years. Mr. Chapin gave a great deal of time to the oversight of the work.

The Secretary,

Indian Affairs.

Wm Gordon
Indian Agent.

Superintendent of Education,

Ottawa, Ontario.

December 28th,
1931.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

When Miss Frances Patterson agreed to teach the school at Island Lake during the summer months, I told her that, if it were possible, I thought the school should be screened. My personal experience at Island Lake in July, 1930, led me to doubt the possibility of carrying on any kind of teaching in a room which was not screened from mosquitoes. I had seen clouds of mosquitoes in China, but the Chinese variety are small and very gentle compared with the ones that they breed in the lakes and marshes of Northern Manitoba. The screening was already on the ground, and Miss Patterson proceeded to have the work done at a cost of $24.98. When she sent the bill for this to Mr. Wm. Gordon, the Agent at Norway House, he returned it, stating that she had exceeded her authority in proceeding with this work without his consent. Now, Mr. Gordon's attitude is perfectly right and I am not complaining about it. I was under the impression that I had discussed this with him during the week that I was at Norway House in July, but it is quite evident that I forgot to mention it to him at all.

I am writing to ask if the Department considers this $24.98 a legitimate charge on their miscellaneous budget. If so, I should be glad to receive a cheque for the amount. If it were not for the fact that Island Lake and Norway House are so isolated and mail service so irregular, I should write to Mr. Gordon and make all the necessary explanations. Under the circumstances, however, I feel that a direct approach to you is justified.

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

Ottawa, December 30, 1931.

Dear Mr. Beaton:

I have your letter of the 28th instant regarding the payment of an account to the amount of $24.95 covering the cost of window screens purchased by Miss Frances Patterson, teacher of the United Church Indian Day School at Island Lake. It is noted that Miss Patterson submitted this account to Mr. Agent Gordon, Norway House, but that he returned same to her on the grounds that the necessary authority had not been obtained by her before making the purchase.

In this connection I have to say that if Miss Patterson has the receipted account, in duplicate, covering the cost of the screening material, and will forward same, the Department will favourably consider reimbursing her for the outlay incurred by her. It is necessary, in order to meet the requirements of the Auditor General, that the account be forwarded in duplicate. If Miss Patterson paid the merchant from whom she obtained the material, the account should be receipted and she should endorse thereon that the material was received and the price charged fair and just. A cheque in payment could then be forwarded direct to Miss Patterson, or, if desired, to your Church treasurer. I regret being unable to forward a cheque until the account, completed as stated above, is received.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I regret that my previous letter concerning Miss Patterson's account of $24.98 was not sufficiently explicit.

The screening which was used was quite evidently sent in with the materials for the building of the school. Miss Patterson made no outlay on this account whatever. Her expenditure was entirely for labor. It undoubtedly involved, as you will realize, the sawing of the logs into the proper lengths, - perhaps even the cutting down of the trees from which the window-frames were made. The bill is for labor only. If you desire Miss Patterson to obtain receipts from the Indians who did the work, covering the amounts expended, these can, I think, easily be secured. There is not any special hurry about paying this account, and I would simply write to her, saying that the requirements of the Auditor General demand this type of voucher. When the account is finally settled, it will be better to pay the amount to our Board and we will deposit it to her credit in the bank at Winnipeg where she has her account.

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 13th instant, in which you express surprise at the request sent forward by the Department to the teacher of the Indian Day School at Island Lake with respect to additional school accommodation that may be needed on the reserve.

I may state by way of explanation that when this Department was reorganized in December 1926, the construction of Indian day and residential schools, which had until that date been undertaken by the Department of Indian Affairs, was transferred to the Surveyors and Engineering Branch of the Department. The officials of this Branch, who have no access to our files, request the fullest possible information with respect to the construction of any school that may be referred to them from time to time. The regular forms upon which this information is usually supplied are sent out to Indian agents who, in turn, secure all the details through the teachers employed on the reserves. The letter dated February 2, 1939, sent to Mr. Grafton, was the usual letter sent out to teachers in charge of schools on reserves where additional accommodation is required.

A careful record is kept of all letters reaching this Department. Dear Mr. Crerar:

I am taking the liberty of writing you direct in connection with the school situation at this point as it concerns the people of our Communion. I have written Mr. Hoey and got a letter today in answer to mine, which is entirely unsatisfactory and in which he conforms my opinion that he has not the slightest grasp of the situation here. In one paragraph he states: "The Department has no knowledge of the existence of Indian day schools at Marias Portage or Wasagamach Bay, nor have we at any time contributed directly or indirectly to the construction or operation of these schools". This from the Director of Training and Welfare of the Department. You will know that the Marias Portage school has operated for years under the auspices of the R. C. Church and the teacher paid through your Department at a salary of ninety dollars per month. We have been told that the wife of this man receives a salary from the Department for teaching the school at Wasagamach Bay. You will also know that the Department built a new school for them at their Mission last year at Marias Portage.

The Wasagamach Bay people were mostly of this communion until the school started there last year. Our application for a school in our building at that point was refused by the Department in 1936 and we find that the R. C. people were given permission and a teacher supplied last summer. Mr. Hoey denies that this is the case.

Here is the situation at Island Lake. We have around 650 Indians in our communion, over 170 children of
school age and one room with seats for 18 pupils to accommodate them. We have continually for the past five years pressed on the Church the necessity of further accommodation here and have seen the R.C. Church get a new up to date school at Marias Portage and a summer school at our point of Wasagamach which was denied us when we made application through the usual channels.

We have made a study of the needs of the people here and submitted plans to the Home Mission Board for what we think would be an ideal set-up for the problem here and have been told that the Department has been approached by the Mission Executives with a view to having something done for the children here who have no way to get any schooling of any kind. The only rise to date is a letter from Mr. Hoey to our tea cher dated Feb. 2nd suggesting that the present one-roomed log building might be enlarged to accommodate the 170 odd children and the letter from the same gentleman today from which the above quotation is lifted. Mr. Hoey's letter of Feb. 22nd tells me that I am not in order writing to the Department and probably he is quite right technically. However, I have written him a letter which I am sure will not please him in which I set out my determination to press the claims for the Island Lake United Church Indians in any direction that may get some action notwithstanding his displeasure.

This is the largest reserve in this part of the country and fast increasing in population. As I see it, Mr. Crerar, you have a great opportunity to make an experiment in something different in Indian education, as I think that you will agree that the present type of residential school is not doing the job. And that is something that cannot be laid at the door of your Department or the present administration. Here you have a large band of Indians. They have no old educational systems to live down, nothing to forget. They are far enough away from outside influences to be free from harmful criticism to enable a new plan of education to get going.

You know that we have one visit each year from the Agent and his party when they pay treaty. It is not
possible for your Agent to have any idea of what would be good for these bush people when he sees them for one day per year.

I have done my best to get the problem over to the Department for the past five years but with so many hands to go through and the last two men, ours and yours not having the slightest knowledge of the problem first hand it is not getting us anywhere. This is my excuse for writing you direct and asking you if it would be possible for you to open a direct route from me to the Department or yourself in order that our views might be made known. I would go at my own expense to Ottawa if you could do this and it would be considerable and I know that if you could get to know the set up you would welcome the opportunity to do what you could to get a worthwhile school plan in operation.

We know that if the present session is concluded without provision made for schools here that another year will pass before anything can be done and I do not want that to happen nor do I think that that is your wish. And if we follow the instructions as laid down by Mr. Hoey nothing possible can be done worth while.

This is written without the knowledge or consent of the Home Mission Board of our Church as were my letters to Mr. Hoey to which he takes exception. I consider that the circumstances and the urgency require your personal consideration and if this letter obtains that I will be content.

With every good wish to yourself and the Party and Principles you represent, I am,

Yours sincerely,

Gavin H. Grieve.

Memorandum:

DR. DOREY:

I am attaching hereto, for your information, copy of a letter received by me from the Reverend Gavin H. Grieve, United Church Missionary, Island Lake, Manitoba.

This letter is, in my judgment, a striking illustration of the misunderstandings and difficulties that are apt to arise when missionaries are permitted to enter into negotiations with the Department in respect to either the construction or operation of Indian day schools.

It is not my intention to acknowledge receipt of Mr. Grieve's letter of March 9.

Mr. Grieve appears to challenge my right to seek on secure information from the teacher in charge of the Island Lake Indian School, who, although nominated by the United Church, is an employee of the Department. If Mr. Grieve does not challenge my right to obtain this information, he resents bitterly my attempt to secure information at this particular time and seems to resent even more bitterly my suggestion that he communicate with the Home Mission Board of the United Church. You can readily appreciate the fact that I am not a free agent in this matter. The information asked for in the letter dated February 2, 1939, is information requested by the Surveys and Engineering Branch - information without which we cannot proceed with the construction of the building. Mr. Grieve, of course, has a perfect right to complain against the inadequate school accommodation at Island Lake. He has the right employed by employees of the Department, and the right to communicate with his federal representative in the Dominion House, who happens in this case to be Mr. Crerar himself. Mr. Grieve has no right, however, to interfere with a Civil Servant in the discharge of his duties, and I must feel free to take whatever steps I may deem necessary to prevent him from indulging in this interference.

I may state that the letter sent to the teacher dated February 2, 1939, is the ordinary letter sent out to teachers and Indian agents employed at agencies where additional school accommodation is requested. In the case of a reserve where a day school is already in operation, the Survey and Engineering Branch would invariably ask if the present building can be enlarged or reconstructed - hence the reference to the enlargement of the school at Island Lake in the departmental letter already referred to. This information when secured is used as the basis of an official questionnaire or report and is submitted by the Indian Affairs Branch to the Surveys and Engineering Branch, the officials of which are responsible for the -
for the actual construction of school buildings.

The regulations governing the expenditure of public funds may at times resemble red tape and are, I know, very trying on the patience. I must state, however, that in my judgment such regulations are unavoidable in a democracy. Ministers may be called upon at any time by Parliament to supply the most up-to-date information on any particular project, and Civil Servants have no alternative but to secure, not only the information necessary for the Minister, but in addition, information that may be demanded by the Auditor General. The Treasury officials and my immediate superiors naturally insist that I secure this information from the senior officials employed by the Department on our reserves throughout the country.

A number of missionaries engaged in work among Indians appear to have convinced themselves that representatives of other denominations laboring in the same district secure greater concessions from the government of the day than they are able to secure. This, in my judgment, is a most unfortunate attitude. I am not sufficiently optimistic, however, nor have I the faith necessary to suggest a remedy. I am enclosing, for your information, a statement of the appropriations either passed by Parliament or now under consideration by Parliament for the erection of Indian day schools since I entered the Department. This statement, you will note, is fully self-explanatory.

When I stated in my letter to Mr. Grieve of February 22nd that the Department had no knowledge of the existence of Indian day schools at Marias Portage or Wasagamach Bay, this information was confirmed by me from the official records and is literally correct. Mr. Phelan, with whom I discussed the matter, had no knowledge whatever of the operation of an Indian day school at either of these points. However, it is just possible that the school referred to by Mr. Grieve as in operation at Marias Portage is the school officially known as the Island Lake R. C. School. This school was not built by the Department, but by the Catholic Church authorities, and was erected on the understanding that the Department would make a small grant toward the cost of finishing material and labour. The grant made amounted to $300. Mr. Blackburn is employed as teacher of the R. C. school at Island Lake and receives a salary of $90 per month, or $10 a month less than the salary received by the teacher in charge of the United Church school.

There is no record here of an Indian day school at Wasagamach Bay. If a school is in operation at that point, the cost of its operation must be borne wholly by the Catholic Church. The Treasury regulations do not permit the payment of a salary to the wife of an individual employed in the government service. Therefore, the rumor to which Mr. Grieve refers, that the wife of the Island Lake school teacher is receiving a salary, is wholly without foundation.

It has been -
It has been the aim of the present administration to provide annually the amount of money necessary to meet the educational needs of the Indian population as the urgency of these needs has been emphasized by the accredited representatives of the Churches. It is my understanding that Dr. Cormie visited the Island Lake district about a year ago and that immediately following that visit the claims of the Island Lake Indians for additional educational facilities were discussed with the Minister here by Dr. Coochiching and myself. It is scarcely necessary to remind you that the Minister himself has experienced the utmost difficulty in securing public funds for the erection of Indian day schools. This difficulty is due in part to the fact that the taxpayers of Canada, who provide the money for the Indian service, have throughout the depression witnessed either the closing of their own schools or the reduction of the operating period of these schools to six or eight months annually.

It is my intention to ask the Minister to secure from the United Church an assurance that the responsibility for the operation of residential schools will be assumed wholly by the Home Mission Board and that the nomination of Indian day school teachers be assumed by the same body. I am convinced that unless these assurances can be given the task of a man occupying the position that I occupy at the moment will become an almost impossible one. My experience has been that just as soon as steps are taken to establish a school to be operated under the auspices of the United Church, local difficulties are ended and that these local difficulties are due wholly to the intervention of missionaries employed on reserves. It is scarcely necessary to recall to your mind the difficulty we experienced at Caughnawaga when the missionary and the members of the Montreal Presbytery visited Ottawa and protested vigorously against the temporary accommodation we had made for the United Church pupils of the R.R. School (Kateri). They said, in the case of Alberni, a very thorough investigation of the educational needs of that district was undertaken by the school Inspector and the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia. These officials spent weeks in carrying out an intensive investigation, in preparing a census of the Indian population and in the preparation of reports. Their recommendation was accepted by the Minister and the officials here but was later overruled when the officials of the United Church in British Columbia, at their annual conference, passed a resolution asking for the rebuilding of the school at Alberni. This pressure ultimately prompted the Government to rebuild at Alberni, despite the recommendations of their own officials. Apparently the delay of the building was charged to us but there has been in my judgment unnecessary delay that might have been avoided, had our officials been permitted to proceed with the building programme, as recommended by them.

The request for these assurances will no doubt reach you from the Minister in due course. I am referring to them now in the hope that you may desire to discuss the matter with the Home Mission Board when it meets toward the end of this month.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

Thank you for your letter of February 22nd here today. I note that you are displeased that I should ever have written you also I note that the Department does not consider any information from my value. In the face of this rebuke I again address you to correct some misstatements in your letter of 2nd ultimo.

First I was not surprised that you had written to Mr. Grafton but was surprised that you should ask him for data which each teacher has supplied to the Department for the past few years in respect to additional seats, paint, etc., from your letter one would get the idea that we were trying to go over the Indian Agents head in these matters which the records will show is not the case. We asked for these things in the usual way and got nothing. Also Mr. Grafton has written a report as you asked for.

Now in respect to R.C. Schools at Marinas Portage and Wasagamack Bay. You say that the Department has no knowledge of any Indian Day Schools at these places nor have you contributed to the construction or operation of these schools. From a man with your official Title of Head of Training and Welfare this statement is to say the least remarkable. Have you ever heard of a school teacher by the name of John Blackburn of Island Lake, or of his wife Mrs. Blackburn? If they were not engaged to teach the schools under the R.C. auspices at Marinas Portage and Wasagamack Bay, what schools are you paying them to teach? A little research work in the records of the Department will show you that the R.C. people have conducted this school for years at Marinas Portage at the expense of the Department also will show you that the new school was constructed there last summer at the expense of the Department. Mr. Blackburn's salary was ninety dollars per month and we heard that Mrs. Blackburn received eighty dollars per month for Wasagamack Bay school. I am sure you will be glad that I have uncovered two of the teachers that you had no knowledge of for you. I am sure that they have done good work here even without their knowing that their names had come to the attention of the Dept. of Training and Welfare.

I have a high regard for the Indian Agent Mr. Lazenby and all our relations have been cordial and entirely satisfactory. Our experience teaches us that something else besides the procedure you outline for us will be necessary if the people under our Church are to be given consideration in respect to education. To this end I will continue to exert every effort to bring the subject before everyone who in my estimation might be able to get some action irrespective of consequences to myself or my effect.
it may have on your responsibilities.

I am more than pleased that you are not responsible for the policy of Indian education.

The very successful efforts of the R.C. Church in obtaining school facilities are not matters that I have ever criticized, indeed I envy their ability and enterprise in getting through the Department schools not only for their own people but for our people.

I am sure that Dr. Dorey could have told you that this missionary had brought his views to the attention of the Home Mission Board through the proper channels at regular intervals for the past five years.
