Sir,

With reference to Mr R.A.Hoey's letter No. 123-4-5 of the 2nd February last addressed to Mr Bernard Grafton, teacher at the Island Lake United Church Indian Day School; also his letter to me of the same file number, dated 17th March, I beg to say that I have received a letter from Mr Grafton, a copy of which I enclose herewith.

With his letter, Mr Grafton enclosed an itemized statement for paint etc. for the interior of the school, and a request for eight or ten more double school desks, and I have summarized the details into the form of a Requisition which I attach hereto in duplicate.

In addition to the materials requisitioned for, Mr Grafton estimates the cost of the necessary labour, at $20.00, which would include the painting of the interior of the school; walla walling, floor, cupboards, tables, washstands; the varnishing of all the desks, and repairing a heave in the floor. The floor, I may add, is maple.

I do not know whether or not the church officials at Toronto have submitted the 'plan' to the Department, to which Mr Grafton makes reference in his letter.

If the materials set out on the attached requisition are approved and purchased, they should be shipped addressed to me at Norway House, c/o Selkirk Navigation Company, Redwood Dock, Winnipeg, so as to arrive here as soon as possible after receipt of consignments, and each package of the shipment should be plainly marked on the outside, "Island Lake U.C.School." No package should weigh more than 90 or 100 pounds, and everything should be very well and securely packed, as they will have to stand considerable handling and hard usage.

Your obedient Servant,

P.G.Lazenby,
Indian Agent.

Dear Dr. Dorey:

I regret that the limited time at my disposal yesterday prevented me from discussing with you certain difficulties confronting us with respect to the construction of an Indian day school at Island Lake.

You may remember that Mr. Grafton, the teacher in charge of the school, is asked in a letter dated February 2, 1939, to supply the Department with certain information with respect to and concerning the availability of labour, lumber, etc. I am sorry to state, however, that the teacher does not appear to be disposed to submit this information.

I am enclosing herewith, for your information, copy of a letter dated February 10, 1939, sent forward by Mr. Grafton to Indian Agent Lazenby. This communication reached me only this morning. The Department has no knowledge whatever of the "complete and most excellent plan" to which Mr. Grafton refers. As a matter of fact, we have not a vestige of evidence on file here that could be likened to such a thing used by the Surveys and Engineering Branch in the drawing of plans for this building. I find it exceedingly difficult to understand why a teacher, who is an employee of the Department, steadfastly refuses to supply us with the information without which we cannot proceed with the project. I have today written to Indian Agent Lazenby and asked him if he knows of any person somewhere which we can secure the information requested for the Surveys and Engineering Branch. Unless this information reaches us almost immediately, I am afraid we shall be unable to proceed with the construction of the school this year. It is just possible, however, that we might purchase a certain amount of material out of this year's appropriation and proceed with the construction next year.

It is my opinion that unless Mr. Grafton has sent forward to you or to Dr. Cochrane the plan to which he refers, he should be asked for his resignation. The Department simply cannot afford to keep in the service employees who refuse to supply us with the information requested by the officials from time to time.

I should like to hear from you with respect to this matter just as soon as you can have time to reply. I am daily expecting an enquiry from the Minister's office with respect to the delay in starting the construction of the school at Island Lake.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, which reached my desk this morning. In respect to Mr. Grafton's letter enclosed with your communication, I note that it is dated February 10, 1939. I should like to know exactly how long it takes a letter to reach the Department from Island Lake via Norway House.

I regret to state that the Department has no knowledge of the "complete and most excellent plan" to which Mr. Grafton refers in his letter. As a matter of actual fact, we have not on file here to guide us a vestige of evidence with respect to conditions at Island Lake, and unless we can secure the information necessary, it will not be possible to proceed with the construction of the school this year or indeed at any time.

The Surveys and Engineering Branch are, as you probably know, responsible for the actual construction of Indian day and residential schools. The officials of that Branch will naturally ask us to supply information with respect to the proposed school and its equipment or if it is the intention to build a separate unit. They will also want to know if lumber can be secured from Island Lake or from a local sawmill or if we have in mind log construction. They should also be supplied with a brief summary of shipping instructions.

I find it exceedingly difficult to understand why the local teacher has refused to supply the information requested. Would it be possible for you to secure this information from any other source? If it is impossible to proceed with the construction this year, would it be practicable to buy a certain amount of the material out of this year's appropriation and proceed with the construction next year?

It is important that we keep in mind the fact that the Surveys and Engineering Branch have had no experience in the construction of Indian day schools until now in the outlying sections of the Dominion. You can readily understand, therefore, why they hesitate to proceed with any project until they have full and complete information at their disposal.

Immediate steps will be taken to supply the paint requested in your requisition of the 18th instant.

Your prompt attention to this matter will be deeply appreciated.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

P. G. Lazenby, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.

Dear Mr. Grieve:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of April 17, in which you submit for my consideration additional information with respect to educational facilities at Island Lake.

I must express regret that the letter dated February 2, 1939, sent out by the Indian Affairs Branch to Mr. Grafton, the teacher at the Indian Day school at Island Lake, has resulted in a long-range general discussion of the actions of certain departmental officials and of the Government's educational policy, particularly in northern Manitoba. It is my opinion that a great many problems brought by you to my attention are of such a character that they might be taken up at a round table conference between the representatives of the Home Mission Board of the United Church and myself.

You will be interested to know that Mr. Grafton's letter in reply to the departmental communication of February 2 reached the Indian Affairs Branch on April 26. This letter, a copy of which I am enclosing for your information, does not contain the details requested by the Branch, nor have we any knowledge whatever of the plan to which Mr. Grafton refers. When the representatives of the Home Mission Board visited the Department, immediately following Dr. Cormie's trip to Island Lake, they discussed with the officials the general educational needs of the district and left behind a number of snapshots taken by Dr. Cormie at the time of—

Reverend Gavin H. Grieve,

time of his visit. They did not at that time or at any time supply the information requested by the Surveys and Engineering Branch.

I am particularly anxious that no misunderstanding should exist in your mind with respect to the policy followed by the Government in regard to Indian day and residential schools. The Cross Lake School (a church-owned building) was destroyed by fire in 1930. The Roman Catholic Church authorities have been demanding the reconstruction of this school since that date. Bishop Lajeunesse, at his own expense, visited Ottawa on a number of occasions and on each occasion supplied us in writing with full and complete information in respect to the Catholic population and the educational needs of the district. When an appropriation of $56,000 for the reconstruction of this school was placed in the 1938-39 estimates, the Chief Architect of the Public Works Department, resident at Winnipeg, was sent to Cross Lake, not only to make an investigation of the building site, but to draw, while there, a complete plan of the building to be erected. This official submitted to the Surveys and Engineering Branch not only a plan of the building but a complete list of the materials that would be required for the entire project. An agreement was then reached with the Church, whereby the actual work of construction was undertaken under the supervision of the Oblate Order.

This year, the same procedure exactly was followed with respect to the construction of the Alberni (United Church) Residential School, British Columbia. An architect was sent from Vancouver to make a complete investigation of the site and to submit a sketch plan of the proposed building. This report and sketch plans were submitted a few days ago to the representatives of the Home Mission Board of the United Church for their approval. There is this difference, however, that the work at Alberni, which it is estimated will cost -
will cost at least double the amount to be expended at Cross Lake, will be advertised and tenders called for the construction. The United Church representatives have never, so far as I am aware, expressed a desire to proceed, under their own direction, with the construction of an Indian day or residential school. If they are now anxious to undertake this responsibility, I can assure you their representations will be very carefully and very sympathetically considered.

I have learned from the departmental records that the letter to which you refer in the penultimate paragraph of your communication is a letter signed by Miss Shoup and is dated Cross Lake, Manitoba, June 16, 1937. In this letter Miss Shoup states: "It is my intention to discuss these suggestions with the Indian agent when I pass through Norway House on my way out in July. I will also send a copy of this letter to Dr. Dorey, our United Church Secretary of Indian Affairs". The suggestions to which Miss Shoup referred in her letter were suggestions with respect to the operation of the Cross Lake School on an annual basis with holidays in April and May rather than in July and August. Miss Shoup's letter was submitted by the Superintendent of Welfare and Training to the Indian agent for investigation and report. Mr. Lazenby replied in a letter dated July 19, 1937.

I find it difficult to fully understand your reference to this letter. Letters reaching departmental officials become, as you are no doubt aware, part of the government records and are liable to be tabled in the House at any time and thus become accessible to the Press. There is nothing whatever in Miss Shoup's letter of a confidential or semi-confidential character, nor was the letter marked "Personal".

In the last paragraph of your letter, you refer to your right to address a letter to myself as

Minister -
Minister of the Department. This is the undisputed right of any citizen of the country. I hope I am not mistaken, however, when I state that I have an impression from your communications that you resent to some extent the action of certain officials in communicating with Indian day school teachers and Indian agents. May I state that the officials are not free agents in this matter. They are compelled to communicate with our field officials from time to time. Indeed, it can be said that our field officials would be of little value to us in our administrative work if we were not in a position to secure from them the information necessary to carry forward the programme of the Department.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 10th instant, in which you refer to a misunderstanding that has arisen between yourself and the Department, in respect to the extension of educational facilities at Island Lake, Manitoba.

I may state by way of explanation that Indian Agent Lazenby visited the Department during the month of January, 1939. At that time we discussed with Mr. Lazenby the matter of school accommodation at Island Lake and ways and means whereby it might be extended. He was not in a position to supply us with much information at that time but suggested that we communicate with you in regard to the matter. I should state also that immediately following the reorganization of this Department, a little over two years ago, the repair and construction of Indian day and residential schools was assigned to the Surveys and Engineering Branch. This is a distinct and separate unit of the Department with an independent status in the Department as the Indian Affairs Branch. The officials of the Surveys and Engineering Branch are not prepared in any instance to proceed with the construction of a school until we have secured for them from the senior official in the district full and complete information with respect to the government buildings already established, the desirability of extending such buildings or the construction of new buildings, as the case may be.

We wrote to you on February 2, 1939. In that letter we asked you to prepare a report stating what provision you considered should be made for the increased number of pupils at Island Lake. You were asked also if it would be possible to enlarge the present building at Island Lake. You were asked if the lumber could be secured locally and thus save the expense of freighting lumber to the school. We intimated to you that you should give very careful consideration to the whole matter and supply as complete information as possible to Indian Agent Lazenby.

I am enclosing herewith, for your information, a copy of your reply to this letter, dated February 10, 1939. If you study this reply you will note at once that it is wholly unsatisfactory to the Department. I might state also that this letter did not reach the Department until April 26. It is just possible, of course -

Dear Sir:

Your letter of the 15th instant to hand. Your kindness in forwarding 10 extra double desks would enable us to accommodate those able to attend our day school at present.

In regard to additional accommodation:

The present school is a log building. I do not think you could enlarge same without tearing it down and re-building with longer logs.
All rough lumber might be secured locally as the Catholic mission across the lake has a saw mill. All finishing lumber, shingles etc., would have to be sent in.

As I will be returning to Island Lake early next week, and as the Hudson Bay Co. erected new buildings last summer, I could obtain accurate information for you as to cost handled price of lumber and cost of labor in connection if you so desired.

Dear Sir:

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Mr R.A. Hoey's letter No; 123-4-5 of the 26th April, which arrived with a small quantity of mail brought in by an airplane bringing in a load of freight for the Hudson's Bay Company, from Winnipeg. The mail service is not as yet on regular schedule.

In reply to the first paragraph of Mr Hoey's letter, I beg to advise that it is impossible to say exactly how long it takes for a letter to reach the Department from Island Lake via Norway House, as there is no post office at Island Lake at the present time, and no mail service to and from that point, as such. Dear Mr Lazenby

When I was in Island Lake last summer Mr. Grieve, our missionary, drew attention to the inadequate provision for the education of the children on that reserve. It appears that the average attendance last year was thirty during the summer and twenty-four during the winter, but that there was seating accommodation for not more than twenty. I understand that there are more than 250 pupils of school age in the vicinity of the school and that the new policy governing the Norway House residential school will close that institution to new pupils from the Island Lake Reserve.

Mr Grieve presented a plan pretty much along the line of the new school at Cross Lake. I handed it on to our office in Toronto, leaving the matter with that office to make what representation to the Indian Affairs Branch they thought wise. I do not communicate direct with the Indian Affairs Branch.

In my report to our office I urged the need of action somewhat along the lines adopted at Cross Lake but was unable to go into details. I felt when I drew attention of our office to the need of some definite and decided change of policy for the education of the Indian children on this Reserve that the details could be worked out by those more familiar with the matter than I.

I have had two conversations with Mr Grafton who is now on holidays, returning to Island Lake to-morrow, and I believe he has written to Mr Hoey on the matter.

Yours very sincerely

My dear Mr. Hoey:

Re - Island Lake Day School

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 21st, addressed to my colleague, Dr. Dorey. The letter has come to my desk for answer, as Dr. Dorey is in the Maritime Province for three or four weeks.

I have gone over the correspondence with your Department in regard to the question of a new school at Island Lake, and I have recalled several conversations that Dr. Dorey and I have had with you in the past year about this matter. I also have before me a letter which Dr. Dorey wrote regarding Island Lake to Mr. Chapin, of Norway House, who wrote us very recently about the situation there.

First of all, let me say that on August 8th, 1938, Mr. Chapin wrote us a letter in which there occurs these sentences: "Norway House treaty is this week, so we are looking for a busy time. I was not permitted to recruit from inland, so did not get a visit to Island Lake, Gods' Lake or Norway House. The Doctor said to get what recruits I could from Cross Lake, so I went up there last week." "...With Island Lake children shut out or coming to residential school, it would be a wonderful thing for the Roman Catholic Church to get a residential school going in there."

Now, it seems strange to me that you say that neither Mr. Phelan nor yourself knows anything of this new policy to which Mr. Chapin refers, and that no changes in the administration of the school at Norway House have been discussed at any time by the officials in recent years. Perhaps you could find out what representations were made to Mr. Chapin at Treaty time last year in regard to this matter. If he is laboring under a misapprehension, we should like to tell him so.

Next, let me say that I have a clear recollection of a conversation Dr. Dorey and I had in your office last year or early this year, when we impressed on you the need of making provision for the children of the Northern Reserves, who hitherto had been accommodated at Norway House. We made special reference...
to Island Lake. We carried away your promise that there would be in the Estimates $4,000, to make at least an addition to the school at Island Lake. We gathered from what you said that this amount would be used to complete the first unit of a building which would ultimately meet the needs of the Island Lake Indians.

Neither Dr. Dorey nor myself has had any defence to make of the kind of letter which Mr. Grieve, our representative at Island Lake, wrote you some time ago. We agree that Mr. Grafton should have sent the information which you desired, in the way you desired it. It seems unfortunate if, because of the difficulty in securing information from Mr. Grafton, who is in fact an employee of the Government and of the Department, the $4,000 in the Estimates this year should not be spent at Island Lake. There is certainly, according to our Superintendent of Missions, Dr. Cormie, an imperative need of immediate action in order to get some kind of adequate school accommodation. I should like to impress upon you the advisability of something being done in this direction at the earliest possible moment, and if there is anything we can do to help secure the information necessary before construction of this new unit is possible, we shall be glad to do it.

We endorse very heartily your suggestion that there ought to be a thorough survey made of the educational needs of the Indians at Island Lake, but if this means another year's delay before any beginning is made, I think this would be very unfortunate. Why not go ahead with the first unit and spend the $4,000, and then by thorough survey find out how much more will be needed? Dr. Cormie may be visiting the area again this year, or at least if we asked him specially to do so, he might be able to arrange it. He gave us a very lucid and comprehensive report last year of the conditions he found on his visit. We communicated to you the facts he presented to us. If you think it would help any to have him go in again, I will see what can be done.

We are anxious that the children of these United Church Indians should have a decent school building, and I do not think we can be blamed for the delay. As it is now, apparently Dr. Cormie and our representatives in Manitoba are blaming us here in Toronto for not making the representations to your Department that we should have made. I do not know of anything more we can do. I note that in Dr. Cormie's letter to Mr. Lazenby, he says that Mr. Grafton has, he thinks, written to you on the matter. Has he sent you the information you desire?

Let me in conclusion urge that something be done this summer to correct the educational conditions at Island Lake.

Believe me,
Very sincerely yours

RBC.MLT

You are no doubt aware that Mr. Lazenby, the Indian Agent at Norway House, visited the Department a few months ago. He suggested that we communicate with Mr. B. Grafton, the teacher in charge of the United Church Indian Day School. We communicated with Mr. Grafton in a letter dated February 2, 1939. Mr. Grafton appeared to be somewhat reluctant to supply the information requested and we have had a number of abusive letters from the local missionary at Island Lake, Mr. Gavin H. Grieve, all of which suggest that the missionary seems to resent the action of the Department in seeking information.

You are aware that the construction of Indian day schools comes directly under the Survey and Engineering Branch. However, the officials of that Branch are not prepared to proceed with the construction of a school until they have secured from us the fullest possible information with respect to the type of construction, lumber or logs, the condition of the present building, basement accommodation, etc. This information is usually supplied in the form of a questionnaire. At this date we have not -

"Mr. Grieve presented a plan very much along the line of the new school at Cross Lake. In addition to this, you might discuss the matter with Mr. Allan, if you can find it convenient to do so. Mr. Allan has had a certain amount of experience in the construction of buildings in outlying districts and might be in a position to give helpful advice.

I should emphasize that under the new arrangement, whereby the Surveys and Engineering Branch are responsible for the construction of Indian day schools,
1. Island Lake School Plan

Reasons for:
1. Due to the nomadic life of the Indians only a small percentage of the children are able to live in the vicinity of the day school.
2. The curriculum of a day school does not contain manual training.
3. The residential schools are exceptionally fine in every way but are much too far above the Indians means for him to apply much that he sees and learns to his after school life.
4. The residential schools do not fit their pupils for after school life, hunting and fishing although they do teach them excellent English.
Island Lake School Plan

Aims: Boys:
1. To give the children training which will be both useful and profitable in after school years.
2. To have living conditions in the school comparable to those attainable by the Indians in after school years and still raise their standard of living.
3. To provide instruction in manual training useful in later life, i.e.,
   1. Trapping
   2. Fishing
   3. Bush carpentry
   4. Gardening
   5. Home making
4. To give all children an opportunity of receiving an education.
5. To instill into the pupils the habits of cleanliness, preparing in advance, independence, etc.
Island Lake School Plan.

Outline of Plan.
1. Buildings. (This is for one unit of plan, about twenty-five or thirty boys).
   a. The present school for cultural subjects.
   b. A log building of two stories with thirty wooden bunks upstairs.
      Having homemade tables and chairs downstairs.
   c. A small log building for manual training.
      The total cost of these two buildings should not exceed five thousand dollars.

2. The cost per pupil for food would be very small as most of it would be obtained from the net and the gardens similar to what they receive at home, and could afford themselves.
(4). 3. Manual Training.

a. Children could be taught:
   1. How to build a good log house.
   2. How to make suitable furniture with the means at their disposal.
   3. How to make snowshoes.
   4. How to make a boat.
   5. How to make a toboggan.

b. They could be given instruction in net making and repairing.

c. Classes could be held during the winter months by a good trapper in the art of trapping. At present boys generally become as good trappers as their instructors. This way all boys would have the opportunity of becoming good and besides learn how to take care of their equipment.

d. During the summer children could plant and care for the garden.
(5): 4. Educational training as at present could be given but in shorter days to allow for extra curricular activities.

5. General training would be incidental and continuous as the needs arose, sports and physical training could be stressed.

This type of school I believe would meet the needs of the children at Island Lake most satisfactorily.

If you give my suggestions any consideration I would be glad to forward a detailed plan as to buildings, equipment and any other matters you may desire.

Permit me to thank you most kindly for your consideration and time.

Yours respectfully,

Bernard Gaffton.

Dear Sir,

Yours of the 24th to hand on last night's mail.
In reply I might review the events of last summer.

Dr. Turpel told me that the Indian Affairs Branch were endeavoring to make some kind of a medical drive against T.B. on the Northern reserves. The funds they had for this purpose were limited so the movement had to be started where it could be best controlled. In Norway House there was both a school and a hospital so that was the logical place to start work, using the facilities of both School and Hospital. Further, the aim was to work more with the younger generation. If a drive were made to put all possible children who were fit in Residential School, where they would be away from the contagion of reserve contact, there would not be room for children from the outside reserves also. So in order to use the School to best advantage, and have the children in it from one locality where medical work could be followed up closely, children could be taken in only from Norway House, though Dr. Turpel said to also include Cross Lake as he is in fairly close touch with that reserve.

The children taken into the School were to be divided into two classes - Those who were normally healthy and could carry on with regular School routine, and those who, while not active, would need special care, rest, food and a modified routine. The latter group were to be segregated as far as possible and the Indian Affairs Branch were to allow twenty-five cents a day extra for their special care.

In acting on the above and writing to Dr. Cochrane I said I regretted that the inland children could not thus have the opportunity of Residential School training. However health is of primary importance and I said I was ready to cooperate with the Department in any move they might promote.
In the fall Dr. Turpel left on leave of absence and Dr. Searle, who was supplying for him, had no instructions re the above mentioned program. So as far as our School was concerned we carried on along the usual lines. We had only four or five children who needed special watching and these have come through the year splendidly.

If the Department has in view a medical drive we are ready to cooperate in any way we can. If that is not to be put into effect just yet we would like the inland Reserves to send some of their children to Residential School. We cannot accommodate all the children by any means but we like to have a percentage from each reserve.

We have only weekly mail service so this cannot go out till next week but I will send it Air Mail to hurry it through from Winnipeg as speedily as possible.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter 123-4-5, dated June 26th. Dr. Cercle is away on holidays and not likely to return before July 31st. The Rev. Father Plourde wired the Bishop at The Pas and yesterday advised me that, with 15 days notice, they could saw from 10 to 15 thousand feet of spruce lumber with their mill at Island Lake. This lumber would be green and would require careful piling so as to dry.

Mr. Lazenby will be at Island Lake July 24th. I would suggest a letter be sent him with a questionnaire covering all the information required. This could be sent out by air mail and perhaps even yet the school could be erected. If not, information would be on hand for next year.

I am not impressed with a winter school on the reserves where the Indians hunt for a living. The Indian either goes with his family out to the trap line or remains at home and cries out for relief. It seems to me the only logical school is a summer school and then close the school in winter and send the Indians away to hunt and trap. I have visited many of these outlying schools and scarcely a child will talk. Boys who have quit school require an interpreter.

Before any expensive schools are built in these outlying points I think all detailed information required should be provided and the Agent should definitely recommend that the school is a necessity and state that he should attend the summer school or during the winter. I cannot help but feel that in many cases we invite hunger and relief by insisting that the children attend school when they perhaps would be learning better how to make a living if out on the trap line with their parents.

If a letter addressed to Mr. Lazenby c/o this office, arrived here by Air Mail not later than Monday the 17th, I could send it North with Nurse Nelson and she could deliver it June 20th. Ottawa should then receive full information not later than June 31st.

Yours very truly,

This includes the Carcross residential school which was totally destroyed by fire early in the year. In view of this fact I am convinced that Parliament would not vote public funds for the construction of a Government-owned building anywhere in the Dominion other than a building fully fireproof throughout. Sir,

With reference to Mr R.A.Hoey's letter of the 14th July, and previous correspondence, in connection with proposals to enlarge the Island Lake United Church Indian Day School, or rebuild, I beg to say that when I was at this reserve on my treaty trip, I discussed this matter thoroughly with both Mr Bernard Grafton, the teacher, and Mr C.H.Grieve, the United Church missionary.

The conclusion arrived at, was that, with the new desks provided this year, and having the interior repainted, (the paint also having been provided), the present building would do. Even if a new, and larger building were erected, all the children of school age could not be provided for, as there are too many of them.

Another aspect of the matter, to consider, is that if we provide a big school there, and then urge the parents to keep their children going to school all through the year, it would mean that the Indians would tend to stay on the reserve all winter, which would be the worst thing that could happen to them. They cannot possibly earn a living on the reserve in the winter, and to encourage them to stay on the reserve would mean that, although their children might get some education, the Department would, without doubt, have to feed the families, and they would eventually become entirely dependent upon the Government for their living. These Indians can only be independent, and stand on their own feet, provided they go out to the bush for about eight months of the year, and to encourage them to do otherwise, for the sake of having their children attend school, would not be good policy.

This school now, with the addition of the new desks -

Island Lake, Man.
July 2nd, 1941.

Mr. Roberts,
Indian Agent,
Norway House, Man.

Dear Sir:

After a survey, the children at Island Lake, or the Garden Hill Reserve, I find that there are one hundred and fifty children of school age, and the teacher informs me that during the summer months when all the people are living on the reserve that the attendance averages around twenty-five.

The difference between the possible and the actual is caused by the fact that the children have not the means of bringing a lunch and the teacher, Mr. Hewitts and I are requesting for a grant of beans, oatmeal and milk and other in order to serve a hot lunch at noon.
We would like to make an experiment of this and report the results to the Indian Department.

We thus request the Indian Department to send us two eighty pound sacks of oatmeal, one hundred pound sacks of beans, a case of canned milk and fifteen pounds of cocoa, together with two large boiling kettles.

Mr. Webster will take the responsibility of seeing that the meal is properly served.

Yours truly,

J.A. McLean
(United Church Missionary)

Rev. W. Webster
(Teacher)
Norway House, Man.,
July 5, 1941.

Dear Sir:

The attached communication has been received from Rev. J. A. McKim, missionary, and Mr. Robert Huestis, teacher of the Island Lake United Church Day School.

I have prepared requisitions covering Mr. McKim's request, but if the Department approves supplying these midday lunch supplies, I would recommend that authority for local purchase be granted in order to obtain quicker delivery, as these supplies would have to go in by canoe freight from Norway House this summer.

Yours very truly,

C. Roberts,
Acting Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.
Ottawa, July 17, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant, enclosing requisitions for supplies for the Island Lake United Church Indian Day School.

I have reviewed the returns for the last two quarters and find that they have only had an enrolment of 8 at this school. It is hoped that the attendance is much larger at the present time.

If you believe it advisable, you may purchase the quantity of oatmeal, beans, canned milk and cocoa which you consider necessary for midday meal purposes, keeping in mind the attendance. I may say that it is not usual for us to give midday meal supplies during the summer months. It is felt that this service should be limited to the winter months.

You may also purchase two stock pots, if you consider these are needed.

In the event of finally deciding to give midday meal supplies to the Island Lake United Church School, you should give similar treatment to the Island Lake Roman Catholic School. When forwarding accounts, however, separate accounts should be submitted for each school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Island Lake (U.C.) Indian Day School: visited 11 Sept., 1947.

Dimensions: 26' x 18' (468 sq. ft.)
Window Area: 33 sq. ft.; 1:14 (pan)

No screen windows or door.

Teacher's desk; 2 chairs; 2 tiny forms.
Stools (boards) for thirty pupils.
Toilets and bathroom good.
Classroom has hardwood floor.
Pencil sharpeners, clock, pots
and pans, 22 coat hooks.
Map of Canada; Union Jack.
Health & temperance posters.

Needs:
Cupboard at X; new insulation under stove.
Blackboard; top-opening windows.

The United Church claims 220 children school age.
Our day school accommodates 30 when there is
a teacher, but none has been nominated.
When the faltering Island Lake sawmill has
finished the current housing project for oldsters
a teacherage should be erected. Mr. Trader Austin
Hodgkinson wants $15 a month for a one-room
hut 18' x 16' that is rather far from the school
and involves a short water crossing.
Teacher would be paid for tutoring Hodgkinson
children outside of Indian school hours.

Indian homes are too scattered to encourage
building one large school.

CAT Clark

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Requisitions for Buildings Supplies for -
(1) Cross Lake R.C. Day School,
(2) Island Lake U.C. Day School.

The above day schools are to be built in the Norway House Agency next summer. As the only means of transportation for heavy supplies is by tractor train, it is necessary to purchase these building materials now.

You will note the following closing dates of tractor train departures,

(a) For Cross Lake, to reach Wabowden not later than 4 March, 1948.

(b) For Island Lake, to reach Ilford not later than 12 February, 1948.

You will note that these requisitions are for the standard bill of materials of our usual one room Indian day school with attached teacherage. The only deletions are for the dimension lumber which our own Indian sawmills are providing. The sole difference between the two requisitions is that we are ordering insul-bric siding and extra nails for Island Lake because the mill there will not turn out lumber siding.

In view of the short period of time left to you to arrange for purchase orders, it is suggested that you order these materials from the same firms who supplied identical materials and quantities.
Ottawa, January 7, 1948.

Mr. E. B. Goodman, Indian Agent,
Norway House, Manitoba.

1948-49 Building Programme - Norway House Agency

Reference your letters of December 19 and December 27 - on File 9-B

We have taken the following action with regard to the proposed building of three new day schools and teacherages in your Agency:

(a) Cross Lake R.C. Indian Day School -

We have forwarded a requisition to our Departmental Purchasing Agent for the building materials listed on your requisition. We have asked that these building materials be ordered to reach Wabowden not later than March 1, 1948. Inspector Hamilton is being forwarded a copy of this letter and is requested to approach Tom Lamb regarding the transportation of these supplies from Wabowden to Cross Lake.

(b) Island Lake U.C. Day School -

We have forwarded a bill of materials for this school to our Departmental Purchasing Agent with the request that the supplies reach Ilford not later than February 12, 1948. We have asked that these supplies be forwarded via Johnson Transportation Company. If Inspector Hamilton wishes to advise concerning the two other transportation companies at Ilford, we will be glad to hear from him.

Your comments concerning the gypsum board have been noted and we have substituted Ten-test, as required.

........... With
With regard to the siding for the Island Lake School, we have substituted Insul-brick for Asbestos-siding shingles. We have found that Asbestos-siding shingles sustain a great loss in shipping even on the railways. Therefore we have replaced this item with Insul-brick and hope that it will prove satisfactory. If you wish literature on the method of applying Insul-brick, I would suggest you contact the firm supplying it when you receive the purchase order.

(c) God's Lake Narrows U.C. Day School -

Unfortunately, North American Buildings Limited have such a large quantity of orders from the Army and Department of Transport ahead of them, that they will not be able to build our prefabricated schools until the late spring. Therefore, we have no alternative other than to place the order for this school and request that it be delivered as early in the winter as the tractor train allows. We may also agree this action, but so many other concerns are ordering prefabricated buildings, that we must wait our turn for delivery.

I would draw your attention to the policy of the Department in naming these day schools so as to provide a minimum confusion in our filing system here. At the present time there is considerable confusion concerning the naming of the schools in your agency. For example, we are now dealing with three Cross Lake Schools, namely,

Cross Lake Residential School,
Cross Lake U.C. Day School,
Cross Lake R.C. Day School.

A similar situation exists at God's Lake, at Oxford House and at Island Lake. The inevitable errors have occurred in filing accounts, letters, etc., and in the filling of requisitions and orders.

I have discussed this matter with Major Clark and we would like to hear your views concerning other names

....... for
for certain of your schools. Similar situations have arisen in other agencies when new schools were being built. For example, we have a school at Fisher River but a new one is under construction there now. Rather than have a Fisher River No. 2, we have accepted Mr. Indian Agent Lasenby's suggestion that it be named the "Burdoch Indian Day School", after the present Chief. Major Clark suggested the name Sagitowock for one of the Cross Lake Schools. We will expect to hear further from you in this regard.

Bernard F. Neary,

Gypsum Wall board - Northern Bay School Construction.

We passed your comments concerning the use of gypsum wall-board to our Engineering and Construction Division.

We have today received a letter from this Branch reading as follows:

"Gypsum wallboard 3/8 inch thick with filled and taped joints is specified for interior walls and ceilings as it has a smooth hard surface for painting approximately equal to that of a hardwall plaster surface. It may be that if gypsum board sheets not longer than eight feet were used, these would withstand the rough handling involved in transportation to distant points, without anything like the 40 per cent loss by damage reported by Indian Agent Goodman of Norway House where sheets up to 12 feet in length were used.

"An objection to 'Ten-Test' is that it is a soft material with edges and surface easily subject to damage not only in transportation but by the ordinary wear and tear of school usage. Also all joints have to be covered with wood strips or moulding to present a neat appearance which would involve a considerable amount of extra material and labour. For Ten-Test 1" thick window frames should be deepened, so that the interior window trim can be correctly applied. The extra thickness of the Ten Test plus the deeper frames will of course add to the cost, and is not required.

"More durable alternative materials than Ten-Test, would be 3/8" Masonite board or ply-wood, both of which should be available."

...... These
These comments are passed for your information and future guidance. In the meantime we have already submitted a requisition covering Ten-Test as the lining for the interior walls and ceilings of the two schools which you will be constructing next summer.

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Further to my telegram of December 15th 1948 ordering supplies for the new Island Lake Combined School and Teacherage, Mr Thompson, carpenter now informs me that further supplies are required and I enclose herewith requisition in quadruplicate covering same and would request that shipment be made as soon as possible as at head of requisition.

The furnace shipped in to Island Lake last winter for use in this school evidently is a coal furnace. Mr Thompson advises that it would be impossible to burn anything larger than stove length wood in this furnace, and I would recommend that a 5' Cordwood Length Furnace be shipped in to take its place. The furnace which is at Island Lake at present was supplied by Neale, Stothard and Chapman, 118 Eighth Street, Brandon, Manitoba and was paid for by this Agency's voucher #688 d/16 August 1948 in the amount of $592.56. The furnace such as illustrated in Ashdown's Catalogue Page H70 #951 B, I believe is the type which should be used in this building. Would you kindly advise as to whether this furnace as described will be supplied as Mr Thompson states he will install same. We would then have present furnace shipped out.

I have been advised by Mr. Hughes, Acting Superintendent at Norway House Agency, that the furnace shipped in last year is a coal burning furnace, and the fire box will only take - if used for wood - an 18" stick. Or in other words, a stick of wood that would only fit an ordinary box stove. If this furnace is put up it would not be able to heat the school, coal being out of the question at this point.

Mr. Jackson:

Re: Forty school desks for Island Lake U.C. Indian Day School.

Our usual practice is to order school desks direct from the manufacturers, and thereby obtain lowest possible prices. If purchased in this way, the price would be approximately $736.70 f.o.b. Unfortunately the above requisition came to us only yesterday, and it would be impossible for the eastern manufacturers to deliver the goods at Ilford by the 28th instant, which is the date of the last tractor shipment for this winter.

Under the circumstances my recommendation is that authority be granted Regional Supervisor Davis to arrange for local purchase of these desks, for delivery within the required time, if it is possible for him to do so. The desks could probably be obtained from Moyer's Limited, Winnipeg, at about $825.00.

Departmental Purchasing Agent.

Attention: Mr. B. F. Neary,

The furnace for Island Lake U.C. School was delayed and delivered to Ilford only after the last tractor train had left for Island Lake. In addition, the furnace for Maria Portage was delayed enroute by the railway. Therefore, these two furnaces are still sitting at Ilford, Manitoba.

I have made inquiries regarding the shipping of these items in by air, and find it is much too expensive a proposition, as the price quoted was in the neighborhood of $1,000.00.

In view of the above I would suggest purchasing Camp Comfort stoves - setting these up in the basement and connecting with pipes - using these until tractor freight opens up again next fall.

I intend to go up to Island Lake whilst Treaty payments are being made, and I will take this matter up with the Brothers in charge of the school to make definitely certain if the makeshift heating arrangements will be satisfactory until shipment of the furnaces can be made.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

We have your letter of the 25th ultimo in which you advise that the furnace for the Island Lake U.C. School and also the furnace for the Island Lake R.C. School, did not reach Ilford in time for winter freight.

The Department approves your suggestion to hold these furnaces at Ilford until tractor freight opens next fall.

We also approve supplying Camp Comfort stoves to the two schools. It is noted that you intend to visit Island Lake at Treaty payment time, and you should inform the management of both these schools regarding the furnaces. At the same time you should give definite instructions regarding the extreme care that must be exercised in the operation of these Camp Comfort stoves, in order to avoid any fire hazards.

Dear Col. Neary:

I am sorry to have been unavoidably delayed in replying to your letter of April 26. It seems to me that to some extent the questions raised have already been touched upon but I should like to elaborate as follows:

1. School on Island:
This location was suggested first because there was a suitable piece of property, secondly a great number of the children concerned live on the Island, thirdly children at the northern part of the area concerned could walk to Rossville by mainland while if the school were on the mainland the children on the Island would have water to cross no matter which way they went. Also the children at the greatest distance from the school (i.e., towards the R.C. school are on the Island). I do not have my map to hand but it also seemed to me that in terms of geography the Island location was more central. I might add that no one up here was dogmatic on this point though almost all concerned felt the Island was the better choice.

2. As to children at the north end attending Rossville I am quite sure that hardly any family included in the area as defined on the map sent in would find it more convenient to go to Rossville. It is a long and difficult walk around the bay over a very poor road or quite a long open distance over the ice in winter. There is of course a sort of in-between area where children could go either way. Perhaps implicit in your question is a further question as to whether the school might not with advantage be located further up
the river. All I can say is that in my opinion, even faced with your question, the answer is still no i.e. that whatever extra distances for any of the children might be involved in the location under consideration this would be more than compensated by improvement in terrain which it would be necessary for them to traverse.

3. Many of the same people signed both petitions. I might say that I personally had nothing to do either with the origination nor signing of these petitions. I expect that some of the same people signed as they do anywhere just on principle. As you are no doubt aware it is not always easy to be certain as to what the real intentions of the Indians are. I think if you examine the lists closely you will not find complete identification. Also two points are worth noting: 1 Some of the people signed the Residential School petition for the sake of others' children in their capacity as members of the Norway House Band. I know this to be true from personal contacts in some cases. Also there are some with large families who, while desiring the day school would still appreciate the privilege of easing their burdens by sending some of their children to Residential school. I realize that with some white people this "shoving off" of children on the government is considered a poor policy; but it seems to me that unless the government is prepared to initiate and supervise a birth control program some consideration of those with large families is warranted. I might say that I seem to be able to find so far little enthusiasm for such a program among Government officials with whom I have discussed the matter.

I think that the real answer to your third question aside from human inconsistency is that the Residential School has a wider social aspect which excites the interest of all concerned. I state this fully aware of the fact that will be those who would like to have
Both schools on the "Let's get everything we can" principle. That persons with this outlook are in the minority in this area I feel is indicated by the readiness of several of the more responsible men in this area to donate firewood to the new school. I might add that in view of the horrible logs which our poor teachers have had to struggle with at Rossville this last winter that this offer is not as trifling as might appear. I do hope that if a school is built as suggested that the local Superintendent will take them up on their offer as it would seem to me an excellent step in citizen training if it could be carried out.

Incidentally we were requested by Dr. Dorey to forward him a list of potential orphans social cases etc for whose benefit a residential school would be advantageous. I have never had opportunity so far to really analyze this community on this basis but would suggest tentatively that such a list from Norway House would seldom be less than 15 and more likely would be about 20 children. I should appreciate it if when you are writing to me at any time you could give me explicit assurance that this policy of confining Residential School education to social cases is to be applied rigidly and impartially to all denominations.

Thanking you for your courteous and prompt attention to suggestions made I am,

Sincerely yours,

Gilbert C. Johnson

Attention Mr. R.C. Ferrier,

Dear Sir:

His Lordship Bishop Charlebois has asked me to bring to your attention a request made on January 22nd, to Mr. W.J. Gordon, Indian Agent at Norway House, in connection with the official recognition of a Roman Catholic Day School at Massinicap, under the name of St. Theresa Indian Day School. I suppose that Mr. Gordon will send you the letter of the Reverend Father.

I wish to add what His Lordship Bishop Charlebois mentions in his letter: "There are already a few Indians on each side of the Mission near the lake. The house of the chief is about a mile and a half away. And I know that other Indians intends to locate themselves in the neighbourhood. It would therefore be a central location for a day school. I believe that a good attendance could be secured. I therefore strongly recommend the official approbation of this school. For the coming year a part of the mission house could be utilized and in 1928 a school house could be built. For the first year if a school teacher is not available, Rev. Father Chamberland, O.M.I., who will be sent to this mission next June could accept the task as he knows English perfectly. If the Department approves, it will be sufficient for the present year to send books, slates, biscuits, etc."

You can judge by yourself of the desire of the Bishop and the Missionary.

With the hope that you will give this request your consideration, I remain

Yours truly,

Sir;

On January 25th I visited the Day School conducted at Island Lake by the Roman Catholic Mission. I found 18 pupils present, all apparently doing well, with Rev. Father Chamberland as teacher.

Below is a copy of a letter received from Rev. Father Dubéau, who has been in charge of the Mission, and which speaks for itself;—This letter was written January 24th, 1928.

"Our day school, opened two years ago at Massinicap, Island Lake, has given good success last winter, and far better this year.

From June 1927 to January 1928, forty-five children have attended the class. The average attendance was, June 29, July 27, August 22, September 17, October 13, November 12, December 18.

All the circumstances, the central place of the mission buildings, the number of the Indians staying, even in winter, at Massinicap, the great desire of the people of having their children educated, the steady attendance we have in class since two years, establish the success of the school.

So, referring to your own letter (File 775-252) and to one (123-12-1) from the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, I am asking the Indian Department to give to our school official recognition and assistance.

Referring to your letter of March 27th last, No.123-12-1, (received in the last winter mail) re the day school conducted at Island Lake by the R.C.Mission, I return the enclosed map, having marked in red ink the location of the R.C.Mission thereon. Dear Sir,

When I accepted, last summer, to come as teacher here at the Island Lake R.C. Indian day-school for a salary of eight hundred dollars a year, I had no idea of what the cost of life out here. If it were the same condition as it is at Norway House, this salary would be satisfactory as I could live on it with my wife and three children; but from Norway House to here we have to pay fifteen dollars a hundred pounds for transportation at our own risks, which means that if a sack of flour costs me seven dollars in Norway House, it costs me twenty-two here and I will be lucky if there is not more than ten pounds lost through an accident of some kind; either it be torn open in a portage or dropped a few times in the rapids, and it is the same for anything else. I write this letter it is to ask the Department...
to be fair and give me a salary that I could make both ends meet. The teacher who was here last year was not married and yet he could not make up with that salary. I do not want to quit but on the other hand I can not afford to keep on with a salary that does not at least cover the essential expenses of life.

Hoping that my request will be approved by the Department and will soon receive a just and fair answer I remain

I just receive your notice saying that the Department has to reduce the salary of all day school teachers by ten per cent. I understand, considering the present state of finance, that this reduction may be fair in many cases; but here at Island Lake it is impossible for me to cut down any expenses as I have already cut down all what I possibly could, life insurance included, and yet the first year I could not make both ends meet and I had a deficit of about seventy five dollars. After the ten dollars per month increase the Department allowed me (years of Oct 24th 1931 no 123-12-1) and for which I was very thankful, I figured that, though it was not any too much I would be able to save a few dollars to cover the $150. I spent to move from Montmartre Sask. to here; and in a few years make enough to pay my fare back; but 10% off my salary means that I can not possibly see the time when I will be able to go out of here. Two years ago when I came here I did not intend to stay here forever.
The teacher who was here for two years before me, with $700 a year, could not make both ends meet and still owes $100. He borrowed from the mission to go back south; and he was single. I am married and have three young children that I must bring up decently. I am confident that the Department will understand that 10% off per month means more to me for my children than $90 a year to the Department of Indian Affairs.

Trusting that the Department considering that we are in a less accessible locality than most other schools and therefore all transportation more expensive and more risky, will agree that it would be only fair that I, or anyone in the same case, should not be included without consideration in a salary reduction.

It is noted from your letter of the 8th instant that the Island Lake R.C. Indian Day School re-opened on June 3, 1940.

Subject: 3 Classrooms-Maria Portage, Island Lake

A.M. On April 24 1948 I visited Maria Portage and found there had been a mass exodus of the entire Indian population. Every man, woman, child and dog had picked up and departed for the Rat Hunt. I inquired of the teachers as to when this exodus took place and they stated it had started shortly after Easter.

The 3 teachers are there but there will be no children attending school for April and most of May. They expect the Indians to start returning about the 20th May. This is the 1st time since I took over the Agency that such a situation has arisen and I do not know how to cope with it or what action I should take. I suggested to the teachers that they remain for the month of July to make up for lost time but their replies were non-committal, but I understood from Mrs Blackburn that she intends to leave as soon as the school year closed to join her husband who has now started a business in the vicinity of Ottawa, at Meach Lake I believe. I have heard no further word from Bishop Lajeunesse with regard to the installation of the Grey Nuns. The 2 teachers Misses Martha & Denise Lauze expressed a wish to teach at Maria Portage for another year. I told them this would be contingent upon the decision reached between Bishop Lajeunesse and yourself. It is evident that a decision of some kind should be reached shortly, otherwise we are liable to find ourselves without teachers for these 3 classrooms at the commencement of the next academic year.

Miss M. Lauze - age 30
Miss D. Lauze - age 20

Therefore there are two teaching Sisters at Norway House: Sister St. Hubert and Sister St. Lucie. Only one of them is entitled to a salary, as the other will teach to the pupils of the Residential school.

There are three teaching Sisters at Island Lake: Sister Gouin, Sister Mary Christine and Sister Pouliot. All of them, at different dates, have already been teachers at Norway House.

In my letter of September 8th, I was advising you that Sister Pouliot had been granted a permit by the Department of Education of Manitoba, because of the following statement in your letter of June 8th (File 123-12-1) to Sister Pouliot: "You would be entitled to a higher salary classification if you held a teaching certificate granted by a Provincial Department of Education."

Three classes have been opened at Island Lake with a total of 95 children. Sister Gouin is teaching to the smallest children.

1.- Can we expect that she will be accepted as third teacher?
2.- Will the salary of Sister Pouliot be increased?

Hoping that these informations will be of some help to you, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Vicar-Apostolic of Keewatin

Ottawa, Ontario
Dear Bishop Lajeunesse:

I was indeed pleased to receive your letter of September 16th and to have clarified to my entire satisfaction, the teaching staffs at the Island Lake R.C. and the Jack River R.C. Day Schools.

The teachers at Island Lake are entitled to the following salaries and classifications:

(a) Sister Mary Christine - Grade 2 $1920.
(b) Sister Pouliot - Grade 1 $1320.
(c) Sister Gouin - Grade 1 $1080.

All the above salaries are effective September 1, 1948 and are for the academic year of ten months. I am pleased to note that Sister Pouliot has a teaching permit for the Province of Manitoba. Unfortunately this is not a Teaching Certificate and is only permission or authority to teach in the Schools of Manitoba. Our salary regulations require that a regular Teacher's Certificate based on attendance at Normal School during a regular session, be obtained before we can grant classification as a Grade 2 or Grade 3 teacher.

At the Jack River School, we have requested our Chief Treasury Officer to forward a salary cheque monthly to Sister St. Hubert who will be teaching the day school pupils. She has been classified as a Grade 3 teacher at a salary of $1800 an academic year, effective Sept. 1, 1948.
I hope that my letter will clarify the points raised in your letter as well as your communication dispelled the doubts in our minds concerning the whereabouts of these teachers.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Most Reverend M. Lajeunesse, O.M.I.,
Vicar Apostolic of Keewatin,
The Pas, Manitoba.

Dear Mr. Neary,

One of the Reverend Sisters of the Island Lake School spends all her free time distributing medicine and visiting the sick Indians on the Maria Reserve. There is no compensation being paid to her for this work. Sir:

I am informed that cheque No. 2454, for the sum of $240.00 issued by the Department in favor of R. Bilodeau, teacher of the Roman Catholic Day School at Island Lake, has been lost.

I handed this cheque to Rev. H. Boissin, in charge of the R.C. Mission at Norway House, as the Mission was sending freight teams in to Island Lake. The cheque was intrusted to the care of one of the Brothers of the Mission. On reaching Island Lake he found that it was gone. There are very few people travelling this road, and almost all of these are Indians, who would, should they find it, turn it in.

It is possible that I may be in error in the number of the cheque. The number given above is the latest of which I have record. It is possible, however, that I might have handed the cheque to Father Boissin in the envelope in which it was received by me, and that the accompanying slip might have gone with the cheque. If a later cheque was issued, say in January, that would probably be the cheque, if forwarded in my care.

Of course Mr. Bilodeau is very anxious about the loss of the cheque, especially as he has a family to support, and the cost of living at Island Lake is very high. Would it be possible for the Department to duplicate this cheque? Should the original be found, we will return it to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Wm. Gordon,
Indian Agent.

Island Lake Man. March 18th 1933

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs Ottawa

Dear Sir,

I certainly dislike very much to have to write to the Department to settle a question I thought could have been settled through the Indian agent long ago; but as the matter has been delayed long enough I refer it to you.

When I first came here as teacher for the R.C. Indian Day-school; my cheques were sent to me through the office of Indian agent at Norway House who generally passed them over to Fr. H. Boisson of the R.C. Mission at Norway House, who then sent them to me by first opportunity. As many times cheques were delayed too long I requested the Department to make all my cheques payable to Fr. M. Lapineuse or the R.C. Diocese of Keewatin. The last cheque I received through the R.C. Mission of Norway House was cheque No. 2454 for June Quarter 1931 which I endorsed in favor of Fr. Lapineuse (end of December 1931).
In April 1932, Brother J. Gosselin of Island Lake returning from Norway House told me that Mr. Boisson of the R.C. Mission had given him a letter with cheque from the Department to me, enclosed. The letter and contents were lost or most likely stolen with some of his clothes from his suitcase on the road. As soon as he noticed the fact he sent word to Mr. Boisson telling him to notify the agent and have the cheque stopped at any bank.

At treaty time July 1932 we had not heard anything yet about it; nothing had been found; I could not see the agent myself but Mr. Dubois of the Island Lake Mission asked him about it, but he did not seem to know or have heard anything. I have received word from Mr. Lapajouesse that the first cheque he received for me was drawn in favor of the R.C. Diocese of Red River for the month of September 1931 and increase of salary for 6 months from January 1931.

If you look up the matter you will find out that the cheque for payment of summer months July and August 1931 was never returned or if so never endorsed by me or other person authorized. I hope these informations will help you in settling a question which has called for an answer long ago. I understand that if the agent had right to get my report and the school was teaching in July and August, he would have right to get paid for my work.

I know there was a great misunderstanding about this matter; still I have two months of sickness account for which I did not get paid as expected last year and understand how hard living is truly high (for example, $40 for a bag of flour).

Re: R.C. Day School

While at Theresa Point, Island Lake on Mar 11th, I inspected the school building, which is too small to accommodate the children of this community.

The present school building has an unfinished upstairs, which could be converted into a classroom of approximately 15' X 24' with an 8' ceiling, which would make a temporary classroom. The material and labor would cost $243.50 and the material supplied locally. If the construction of this classroom should be approved, a second teacher would be required, for whom board and lodging is available. As it is unlikely that any new school can be built at Island Lake prior to the summer of 1947, I recommend that this scheme be given consideration; the building is in good condition, and should a second school eventually be built, the upstairs could readily be converted at little expense into living quarters for a teacher. Island Lake and 1 school and 1 residence U.C. Oxford House or any other denomination or any other place where they see fit.

There is no-one in this country that I know of who can take on this work on a contract. There are 2 or 3 fairly good self taught carpenters whom to date I have been unable to contact as they are away at the Rat Hunt. There is enough local labour to do the proper supervision. I have already submitted requisitions to Ottawa for building supplies needed for construction of items 1 and 2 in your letter. I will go ahead with this program and do the best I can with whatever unskilled self-taught native artisans I can command.

If you know of anyone in Winnipeg who would be willing to come out and supervise this work for the summer, it would be appreciated if you could obtain his services and let me know. In any event apart from the excavation of basements, no work of construction can go forward until supplies arrive by boat from Winnipeg. I figure on supplying the lumber locally.

I acknowledge receipt of your letter of September 27, 1947 file 123-12-5(WT1).

I was at Maria Portage last Sunday morning. As no-one was around I walked through the school building and examined both classrooms. The Junior classroom had every appearance of not having been in use for days; dust lay thick and undisturbed on all the desks including the teachers', and the register had not been entered since September. Later in the day I had a talk with Father Fleury, parishioner in charge and he told me that the classroom had not been in use for a week as the attendance had fallen off owing to the departure of many families for fall fishing. I discussed with him the opening of a 3rd classroom and he informed me that it would only be worth while for 6 months of the year, the same being September, January, February, March, April, June. He stated that he was quite willing to rent to the branch the Parish Hall for a small nominal fee, which he would not at the time name.

In the 3rd para of your letter you state the Department is requested to accept the services of Miss Martha Laune as teacher of the 3rd classroom. Miss Martha Laune is already employed as a teacher by the branch in the 2nd classroom above referred to. Her sister Denise is employed by Mrs Blackburn to instruct her child Mark but I understand from Father Fleury that she would be available at any time to teach the 3rd classroom if it is open.

As there was no immediate need in having the Staff Questionsirre and T.D.I filled, I used them for Mr. Toole, teacher of the C of J Jack River School. Will you please therefore, send me some more blank forms.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

Mr. E.B. Goodman, Indian Agent,
Norway House, Manitoba.

We have your letter of the 22nd ultimo, with reference to the Island Lake R.C. School. In view of the information contained in the first paragraph of your letter, there is no necessity for opening the third class room at the present time.

Do you consider it advisable to open a third class room during the months of January, February, March and June, 1943? Before authorizing the opening of a third class room we would like to be definitely assured that there would be sufficient attendance to justify the services of a third teacher.

It occurred to us that possibly the Sub Agent, Mr. Stevenson could visit this school monthly and let us know the number of children in attendance.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Island Lake R.C. Indian Day School.

Further to my letter of April 6, we have now been advised by Mr. Blackburn that Bishop Lajeunesse is having some difficulty in securing the services of teaching Sisters for the above Indian Day School. It is understood that in the event that the Sisters cannot take over the school for 1948-49, the two Laume sisters are willing to stay on. A third teacher, Miss Yvette Roy, is also understood to be available.

I have written to Bishop Lajeunesse in Montreal in order that he might confirm the facts as presented above. In the meantime we will expect to hear further from you with regard to the purchase of Mr. Blackburn's warehouse. It would seem that in either event, we are assured of teachers at Island Lake and that we will have to consider the provision of accommodation for them.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
May 20, 1948.

Mr. E. B. Goodman,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
Norway House, Manitoba.

Island Lake N.C., Indian Day School.

Reference your 9-ii (123) of 16 April

I have for answer your above letter and note your comments with regard to the Blackburn warehouse.

I have this afternoon had an interview with Bishop Lajeunesse and he advises me that he has definitely made arrangements for Sisters to take over the Island Lake School. I understand that Sister Christine from Jack River and Sister Pouliot, formerly at Jack River, will be moved to Island Lake to take over the new school. The Bishop is quite prepared to have these Sisters live in the Rectory this winter and to wait until next summer to build them a proper teachersage.

He is entirely in agreement with you about the Blackburn warehouse and feels also that it would be more advisable to erect a proper teachersage rather than to convert a makeshift building.

However, he has drawn to our attention the need for a third classroom at Island Lake and has suggested the possibility that Mr. Blackburn's warehouse could be converted quite easily for such a use. If you concur in this recommendation I would like to be advised so that I can make a firm offer to Mr. Blackburn. I had intended to suggest to him the sum of $2,000.00 (if you agree). I advised the Bishop that
no funds had been provided in this year's estimates for the construction of such a teacherage but that we would endeavour to secure sufficient funds to purchase the building materials for shipping in this winter. I understand that we can buy lumber from the R. C. mill at Island Lake at a very reasonable cost. Therefore, I am returning to you the bill of materials, so that the lumber which can be supplied from the R. C. mill can be deleted. We will then have on hand a bill of materials for outside purchase. If you could do this deletion and return the bill here we can begin to negotiate for the purchase of the remaining requirements.

I understand that Brother Boucher will be nominated by Bishop Lajeunesse for the construction of this teacherage.

It will not be possible for the Sisters to report to Island Lake until the middle of August. Therefore I would suggest that the school term re-open on 1 September, 1948.

Bernard E. Heary,
Superintendent of Education.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Island Lake R. C. Indian Day School.

At Island Lake we have two separate Indian settlements, one at Maria Portage and the other some 10 miles away at Garden Hill. At Maria Portage we have a day school which has now grown to three classrooms with an attendance of nearly 100 pupils. We have never had a teachers' residence at this point but have rented a small house from the R. C. Missionaries for use by the teachers.

Unfortunately, this teachers' residence was burned on December 11. Arrangements have had to be made to house the three teachers temporarily accommodated in the Priest's residence. The Priest and the brothers have moved out to a small shack in order to permit this arrangement.

We have had some correspondence with Mr. Indian Superintendent Goodman with regard to the purchase of a ware-house from Mr. Blackburn, who was a free trader at Maria Portage. Mr. Blackburn erected this ware-house in September 1946. You will find enclosed a complete description of this ware-house as submitted by Mr. W. L. Stevenson, Assistant Indian Agent at Island Lake. There is little doubt about the fact that this building is well constructed and could be quite easily adapted for use as a teacher's residence.

Mr. John Blackburn, who was at one time one of our day school teachers, recently visited the department and offered to sell this building to the Department at cost less the amount which was received from the insurance company for scouring which it obtained in the fire. This building cost $2,600.00 and he
received $200.00 from the insurance company. Mr. Indian Superintendent Goodman has recommended the purchase of this building at the price of $2,000.00. Mr. Blackburn has indicated that he is willing to accept this price.

In addition to the purchase of the building, Mr. Goodman has also recommended that we purchase the following furniture which Mr. Blackburn has available at Island Lake:

(a) Chesterfield and chair (good quality).
(b) Dining room suite consisting of table, end tables, 5 chairs and buffet.
(c) Kitchen table.
(d) Ice-box
(e) Gasoline washer, in good condition.
(f) Knives, forks and cutlery.

Other incidentals.

Mr. Blackburn has priced these items of furniture at $500.00 and Mr. Goodman has recommended their purchase at this price.

This will provide us with three classrooms at Island Lake and with some of the furniture required for the teacherage. It will not solve the problem of teacher's accommodation. Fortunately, Bishop Lajeunesse has offered the use of the Priests' residence for the three Sisters who will teach there next year. The Priest will live in a small shed during the winter in order to accommodate the teachers.

It will be necessary to ship in building supplies for a teachers' residence during the winter but this will be the subject of a further memorandum.

While at Norway House I was looking over the correspondence, and refer to your letter files 123-12-5-8 and 123-10-1, of May 20th, regarding the taking over a building which is an old warehouse, from Mr. Blackburn, at the cost of $2,000.00. I inspected this building and the size is about 30 x 24. It is built of one ply rough lumber; the floor is also rough lumber, and is on a foundation which is just posts. It has one door, but no windows or ceiling, and the studding is 2 x 6. I do not consider this building is worth $2,000.00, and would suggest around $1,000.00 would be a good price for it.

To remodel this into a school will be fairly expensive, as a chimney has to be put in, sheeted and insulated, also windows. It is very doubtful if we can get this material in at this time of year. However, in the event of purchasing, if the mill can turn out enough material, it could be sheeted with our own lumber and papered on the inside and insulated.

I would recommend that the Department take up with the Bishop the matter of using half of the Hall. At present half of this building has been fixed over as a Priests' residence, as the Sisters are going to live in their present quarters. This building would also need some remodelling, but this could be done by them and rent paid to the Church which would be high
enough to cover any alterations that would be necessary. The Sisters from Norway House will be moved in August, and we should take action as soon as possible to get matters straightened up.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.
