Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Island Lake R. C. Indian Day School.

At Island Lake we have two separate Indian settlements, one at Maria Portage and the other some 10 miles away at Garden Hill. At Maria Portage we have a day school which has now grown to three classrooms with an attendance of nearly 100 pupils. We have never had a teacherage at this point but have rented a small house from the R. C. Missionaries for use by the teachers.

Unfortunately, this teacherage was burned on December 11. Arrangements have had to be made to have the three teachers temporarily accommodated in the Priest's residence. The Priest and the Brothers have moved out to a small shack in order to permit this arrangement.

We have had some correspondence with Mr. Indian Superintendent Goodman with regard to the purchase of a ware-house from Mr. Blackburn, who was a free trader at Maria Portage. Mr. Blackburn erected this ware-house in September 1946. You will find attached a complete description of this ware-house as submitted by Mr. R. L. Stevenson, our Assistant Indian Agent at Island Lake. There is little doubt about the fact that this building is well constructed and could be quite easily adapted for use as a teacher's residence.

Mr. John Blackburn, who was at one time one of our day school teachers, recently visited the Department and offered to sell this building to the Department at cost less the amount which was received from the insurance company for scorching which it obtained in the fire. This building cost $2,600.00 and he
received $200.00 from the insurance company. Mr. Indian Superintendent Goodman has recommended the purchase of this building at the price of $2,000.00. Mr. Blackburn has indicated that he is willing to accept this price.

In addition to the purchase of the building, Mr. Goodman has also recommended that we purchase the following furniture which Mr. Blackburn has available at Island Lake:

(a) Chesterfield and chair (good quality).
(b) Dining room suite consisting of table, end tables, 5 chairs and buffet.
(c) Kitchen table.
(d) Ice-box
(e) Gasoline washer, in good condition.
(f) Knives, forks and cutlery.

Other incidentals.

Mr. Blackburn has priced these items of furniture at $500.00 and Mr. Goodman has recommended their purchase at this price.

This will provide us with three classrooms at Island Lake and with some of the furniture required for the teacherage. It will not solve the problem of teacher's accommodation. Fortunately, Bishop Lajeunesse has offered the use of the Priests' residence for the three Sisters who will teach there next year. The Priest will live in a small shed during the winter in order to accommodate the teachers.

It will be necessary to ship in building supplies for a teachers' residence during the winter but this will be the subject of a further memorandum.

ISLAND LAKE, Manitoba.

The information which we have available does not indicate that the provision of this school should be given any immediate priority. A day school (now three rooms) has operated successfully at Maria Portage for some years. There has been some competition evident between the two denominations working in this area. As I have previously intimated to you, I had hoped that the United Church would not press for the rebuilding of the Norway House Residential School but would have been satisfied with the erection of day schools on the various reserves. However, with the preparation of a petition from the Roman Catholic Missionary of Island Lake, we were soon advised that the United Church would press for the rebuilding of the Norway House Residential School. Unfortunately, there have been instances in the past of the Churches using residential schools as a means of proselytizing the Indians and it would seem that care will have to be taken in determining the exact educational needs of these Indians.

An educational survey committee is therefore recommended in this area also. For its composition I would suggest the following members be considered:

(a) Mr. A. J. Doucet, Supervisor of Vocational Training, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

(b) Provincial School Inspector nominated by the Manitoba Department of Education.

(c) Roman Catholic Missionary nominated by the Oblate Order.

30th August 1936.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter No; 123-12-5 of the 17th Instant, and in reply to say that the house in which the teacher of the Island Lake Roman Catholic Indian Day School lives, is the property of the church.

In reply to instructions that in case the house is the property of the church, I should state what rent I consider might be allowed, I beg to say that I fail to see why any rent at all should be allowed. The teacher is paid a good salary at this point, and I am of the opinion that he should be expected to pay his own personal expenses from his salary, as other teachers have to do. However, if the Department feels that this teacher's rent should be paid, I consider that $8.00 per month would be a fair rental.

With reference to the matter of erecting a new school building, as mentioned in the final paragraph of the above mentioned Departmental letter, I beg to say that this is being dealt with in a separate letter of this date.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Ref Island Lake R.C. Indian Day School.

In my letter dated 16th December 1947 under file 17-A, I informed you of the destruction by fire of the R.C. Mission, Maria Portage, on December 11th. This building was used as a teacherage for the R.C. Day School, and for its use the Department paid rent. The teachers, Mrs. Blackburn and Miss Martha Lauze, have been temporarily accommodated in the Priests house.

On December 17th I received the following wire from Assistant Agent R. L. Stevenson:

"BLACKBURN WILL SELL WAREHOUSE FOR TEACHERAGE TWENTY SIX HUNDRED DOLLARS/WOULD REQUIRE FLOORING WALLBOARD NAILS/TWENTY EIGHT FT. EIGHT INCHES FLUE LINING/EIGHT HUNDRED AND FORTY SIX POUNDS CEMENT/FURNACE AND PIPING/ICE BOX STOVE/BEDROOM FURNITURE/BEDDING/IN/OUT TOILET/SINK KITCHEN CHAIRS AND DISHES BLACKBURN WOULD SELL CHESTERFIELD AND CHAIR/DINING ROOM SUITE/KITCHEN TABLE/ICE BOX GASOLINE WASHER IN GOOD CONDITION/AND INCIDENTALS/FOR FIVE HUNDRED DOLLARS/AGREE THAT TEACHERS MOVE FROM MISSION HOUSE AS SOON AS POSSIBLE STOP MARIA PORTAGE MEDICINE SUPPLIES BURNED REPLACEMENT URGENTLY REQUESTED BY MRS BLACKBURN"

The warehouse referred to is a well constructed building but has no basement or concrete foundation. I have never observed the premises with a view to converting it into a dwelling, but it seems to me it would require additional doors, windows and other materials. I do not feel justified in making a recommendation with regard to any purchase until I have made a thorough inspection, but from recollection the price seems high. I wired on December 15th for authority to fly to Island Lake, but to date have received no reply.

I recommend the purchase of the household furnishings and equipment as listed and at price requested, $500.00, but this again would be contingent upon our acquisition of the warehouse for a teacherage. I will write you again as soon as I have made an inspection of the building in question. There is an urgency in the housing of these people which might outweigh to some extent the consideration of the exact valuation.

E. B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.

In reply to your letter of February 11th 1948 file 123-12-8(EL) as far as I know there will be at least 4 people residing in the Teacherage when it is built. I have been informed verbally by Bishop Lajeunesse through Father Trudeau of Cross Lake that they are sending in 3 or 4 sisters to take over 3 classrooms in the Blackburn's house which Mr Blackburn states will be in July. Mr Blackburn is closing out his business in Island Lake and I do not know his future plans but anyway he will not be living in the house.

I have also been informed by Father Trudeau speaking on behalf of Bishop Lajeunesse that they are prepared to take over the warehouse of Mr Blackburn's and convert it into a residence for the Priest and brothers and that they will provide temporary quarters in the present men's residence for the sisters. The Sisters will be the Order of Grey Nuns, however the whole future set up is in a rather nebulous state and nothing can be done about building a teacherage until the summer of 1949.

E.B. Goodman,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 4, 1948.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Island Lake R.C. Indian Day School

At Island Lake we have two separate Indian settlements, one at Maria Portage and the other some 10 miles away at Garden Hill. At Maria Portage we have a day school which has now grown to three classrooms with an attendance of nearly 100 pupils. We have never had a teacherage at this point but have rented a small house from the R.C. Missionaries for use by the teachers.

Unfortunately, this teacherage was burned on December 11. Arrangements have had to be made to have the three teachers temporarily accommodated in the Priest's residence. The Priest and the Brothers have moved out to a small shack in order to permit this arrangement.

We have had some correspondence with Mr. Indian Superintendent Goodman with regard to the purchase of a warehouse from Mr. Blackburn, who was a free trader at Maria Portage. Mr. Blackburn erected this warehouse in September 1946. You will find attached a complete description of this warehouse as submitted by Mr. R.L. Stevenson, our Assistant Indian Agent at Island Lake. There is little doubt about the fact that this building is well constructed and could be quite easily adapted for use as a teacher's residence.

Mr. John Blackburn, who was at one time one of our day school teachers, recently visited the Department and offered to sell this building to the Department at cost less the amount which was received from the insurance company for scorching which it obtained in the fire. The building cost $2,600 and he received $200 from the insurance company, so the building would cost $2,400. Mr. Indian Superintendent Goodman has recommended
the purchase of this building and has submitted a report as to the windows, doors, etc., which would be needed to convert this building from a warehouse to a teacherage. You will note that the building is strongly constructed of 4 x 6 squared timbers with 2 x 8 joists.

In addition to the purchase of the building, Mr. Goodman has also recommended that we purchase the following furniture which Mr. Blackburn has available at Island Lake:

(a) Chesterfield and chair (good quality)
(b) Dining room suite consisting of table, end tables, 5 chairs and buffet
(c) Kitchen table
(d) Ice box
(e) Gasoline washer in good condition
(f) Knives, forks and cutlery,
Other incidentals.

He has placed a price on these of $500.

The only way of reaching Island Lake with supplies is by tractor train during the months of January, February and March. It is understood that the last tractor train has now left for Island Lake and that we will therefore not be able to get in supplies or materials until January 1949. Therefore, it would seem a sound proposal to purchase this building and furniture at these prices. It is understood that Bishop Lajeunesse is prepared to have his Priest and Brothers live in this ware-house and to have the three or four Sisters who are taking over this school next year, live in the Priest's residence until the ware-house - teacherage can be properly fitted up. It is estimated that some $1,600 will be required to convert this ware-house into a teacherage. I would recommend that in view of the very isolated situation at Island Lake you approve the purchase of this building and furniture from Mr. Blackburn at the above prices.

Director
Qua I, line 2: "send your mails" - 9 by air, 10 by water.

I don't see any cheaper alternative to the plan you suggest.

EX'D.

All indications are that this Indian settlement is likely to last a long time.

Island Lake R.C. Indian Day School.

Reference your 9-B (123) of 16 April

I have for answer your above letter and note your comments with regard to the Blackburn warehouse.

I have this afternoon had an interview with Bishop Lajunesse and he advises me that he has definitely made arrangements for Sisters to take over the Island Lake Day School. I understand that Sister Christine from Jack River and Sister Pouliot, formerly at Jack River, will be moved to Island Lake to take over the new school. The Bishop is quite prepared to have these Sisters live in the rectory this winter and to wait until next summer to build them a proper teacherage.

He is entirely in agreement with you about the Blackburn warehouse and feels also that it would be more advisable to erect a proper teacherage rather than to convert a makeshift building.

However, he has drawn to our attention the need for a third classroom at Island Lake. He has suggested the possibility that Mr. Blackburn's warehouse could be converted quite easily for such a use. If you concur in this recommendation I would like to be advised so that I can make a firm offer to Mr. Blackburn. I had intended to suggest to him the sum of $2,000.00 (if you agree). I advised the Bishop that
no funds had been provided in this year's estimates for the construction of such a teacherage but that we would endeavour to secure sufficient funds to purchase the building materials for shipping in this winter. I understand that we can buy lumber from the R.C. mill at Island Lake at a very reasonable cost. Therefore, I am returning to you the bill of materials, so that the lumber which can be supplied from the R.C. mill can be deleted. We will then have on hand a bill of materials for outside purchase. If you could do this deletion and return the bill here we can begin to negotiate for the purchase of the remaining requirements.

I understand that Brother Boucher will be nominated by Bishop Lajeunesse for the construction of this teacherage.

It will not be possible for the Sisters to report to Island Lake until the middle of August. Therefore I would suggest that the school term re-open on 1 September, 1948.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Inland Lake R. C. Indian Day School.

At Island Lake we have two separate Indian settlements, one at Maria Portage and the other some 10 miles away at Garden Hill. At Maria Portage we have a day school which has now grown to three classrooms with an attendance of nearly 100 pupils. We have never had a teacherage at this point but have rented a small house from the R. C. Missionaries for use by the teachers.

Unfortunately, this teacherage was burned on December 11. Arrangements have had to be made to have the three teachers temporarily accommodated in the Priest's residence. The Priest and the Brothers have moved out to a small shack in order to permit this arrangement.

We have had some correspondence with Mr. Indian Superintendent Goodman with regard to the purchase of a ware-house from Mr. Blackburn, who was a free trader at Maria Portage. Mr. Blackburn erected this ware-house in September 1946. You will find attached a complete description of this ware-house as submitted by Mr. H. L. Stevenson, our Assistant Indian Agent at Island Lake. There is little doubt about the fact that this building is well constructed and could be quite easily adapted for use as a teacher's residence.

Mr. John Blackburn, who was at one time one of our day school teachers, recently visited the Department and offered to sell this building to the Department at cost less the amount which was received from the insurance company for scouring which it obtained in the fire. This building cost $2,600.00 and he
received $200.00 from the insurance company. Mr. Indian Superintendent Goodman has recommended the purchase of this building at the price of $2,000.00. Mr. Blackburn has indicated that he is willing to accept this price.

In addition to the purchase of the building, Mr. Goodman has also recommended that we purchase the following furniture which Mr. Blackburn has available at Island Lake:

(a) Chesterfield and chair (good quality).

(b) Dining room suite consisting of table, end tables, 5 chairs and buffet.

(c) Kitchen table.

(d) Ice-box

(e) Gasoline washer, in good condition.

(f) Knives, forks and cutlery.

Other incidentals.

Mr. Blackburn has priced these items of furniture at $500.00 and Mr. Goodman has recommended their purchase at this price.

This will provide us with three classrooms at Island Lake and with some of the furniture required for the teacherage. It will not solve the problem of teacher's accommodation. Fortunately, Bishop Lejeune has offered the use of the Priests' residence for the three Sisters who will teach there next year. The Priest will live in a small shed during the winter in order to accommodate the teachers.

It will be necessary to ship in building supplies for a teachers' residence during the winter but this will be the subject of a further memorandum.

In the meantime it is recommended that approval be given to the following expenditures:

(a) The purchase of Mr. Blackburn's store-house for the sum of $2,000.00.

(b) The purchase of Mr. Blackburn's furniture as listed, for the sum of $500.00.

Dear Sir:

Re: Teacherage of Island Lake, R.C. Indian Day School.

Please find enclosed the plans requested in your letter dated November 23rd for the Teacherage of the Island Lake R.C. Day School. In my reply of November 25th, I have informed you that the requested plans were at the time at the Island Lake Mission in order to be looked over and checked by our constructor, the Rev. Brother Ed. Boucher, O.M.I., who just returned them to us.

Herewith also you will find a list in triplicate of the materials required for the construction concerned. I would suggest that the ultimate date to have all these materials assembled at Ilford, Man., be next February 15th, 1949. From there, as you probably know, they will be hauled by tractor to Island Lake. Since all the supplies for the mission are also directed through Ilford, it would be advisable, in order to avoid confusion, that all the building materials for the Teacherage be addressed to the name of "R.C. Day School, Island Lake, Man."

Our list mentions a water pump & engine only, we leave to you to decide whether the Teacherage will be provided with running water or not. The list will have to be adapted according to your decision. Moreover, there is the heating system to decide upon and approve, and to this effect we leave it to you to have a plan made for the installation of the suitable hot air furnace and air conductors to the different rooms, etc., It shall then be required to send the complete heating system for the above Teacherage, as nothing of this equipment appears on the enclosed lists of building materials.

Hoping that you will find everything quite in order and that you will do your utmost to have every item at Ilford for above mentioned date so that no delay shall hinder transportation before the Spring break-up.

Wishing you but the best for a Merry Christmas and a very Happy New Year! I remain,

Yours very truly,

Re: Island Lake R.C. Indian School.

Dear Sir:

In order to reply to your letter, November 23rd., I wish to say that plans together with bill of materials have been sent, before freeze-up, to Rev. Bro. Ed. Boucher, at our Island Lake Mission, to be looked-over and checked. We hope that they will be returned as soon as communications will be resumed.

In the meantime, may I refer you to a copy of the same plans and bill of materials which were given to Mr. Goodman by Rev. Fr. Trudeau, at the end of last February, at Cross Lake. I happened to see them in your office, at my first visit, shortly after Easter. I believe this list you have already on hand to be fairly accurate and that very few modifications will be made if any. If you could not find the same, please let me know by return mail and I may be able to procure another copy for you.

Now, dear Sir, I would like very much to have for our files a written statement of what was understood between the Indian Department and our Corporation regarding the erection of the Teacherage for the Island Lake R.C. Indian Day School, viz., the wages of the Brother in charge, the price of the lumber, the supplying of the materials that will not be found locally, transportation, payment of the labor, the mode of presenting labor returns and other claims, etc. As I am often away from home, I would deem it very important to have everything well set-up in order to avoid every possible misunderstanding that otherwise might very well arise.

Yours very truly,

January 20th, 1949.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary, Superintendent of Education,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

In reply to yours of the 19th instant, here are the informations I am able to give you regarding your request.

1. The height of the basement will be nine feet high from floor to floor.

2. The clearance between the basement floor and the beams is eight feet high.

3. The Partitions in the Sisters' dormitories are not full and are opened below and above.

4. I suppose that you mean the windows of the Sisters' dormitories, if so, the sizes of these windows are those listed on Sheet 1, asking for 7 cheakrail windows, 2 lights. size: 16"x 20", whose outside measures are: 20" wide x 46" high.

5) As I do not see any chimney flues ordered for the chimney, and that I am too far to discuss this matter with our Brother for a rush answer, I presume that he was intending to build same without flues. But I surely prefer to have 2 separate flues in a single chimney. As for the sizes, I suggest for the kitchen stove: 8½" x 8½" flues, and the other for the furnace: 8½" x 10", presuming that the last size will be sufficient for the proposed furnace.

Moreover, with the sufficient flues to be ordered, you shall have to check if there are sufficient chimney red bricks, which I doubt, to complete this rectangular chimney. As there is no lime ordered for brick mortar, I presume they will need a few sacks. It would be wise to send some with the bricks, etc..

Sorry that we are so far apart from Island Lake to reach and discuss such matters with our Brother builder. Nevertheless, I trust this will give you the informations you require.

With best regards, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Vicar-Apostolic of Keewatin.
January 21st, 1949.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary, Supt., of Education,
Dept., of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Replying to yours of the 18th instant, your file 517-8 (E), may you be informed:

1. That I took notice that blankets, sheets, and comforters are not to be supplied by the Department.

2. As the Island Lake Mill shingles are not suitable for the Teacherage as per Mr. Hughes statement, I take for granted that your Dept., will send the required shingles.

3. I am greatly surprised to hear that you are intending to take the lumber for the R.C. Teacherage and School from the Dept., sawmill at Island Lake!

In all our previous talks it was always understood that the lumber needed would be made by the R.C. Mission sawmill in order to give work to our Catholic Indians during the coming months. You no doubt remember the lengthy discussion we had in your office with Rev. Father O. Plourde, O.M.I., on the cost of the required lumber for the R.C. Teacherage and School at Island Lake, Man.,

I understood by your statements that this matter was settled and that the R.C. Mission had to go ahead with the manufacturing of this lumber. In fact, the builder Brother wrote us today that over a thousand logs are already cut and this would give some sixty thousand feet of lumber. Permits has been paid for cutting logs. Moreover, we have already bought a $3,000.00 new tractor already at Ilford, Man., for the hauling of these logs and to supply power to our sawmill, etc. We would never have bought this tractor had we known that we were not to supply the required lumber for the Teacherage and School. Neither engaged Indian laborers for the cutting, etc., of these logs allowed by permits.

I hope that you shall write me soon about this matter, giving me the clear facts about this lumber question. Moreover, kindly let me know in details all what is to be expected from us and all what we are to expect from your Department, in this question, in order to avoid any misunderstanding between all concerned about the R.C. Indian Day School and Teacherage. I remain,

Sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Vicar-Apostolic of Keewatin.

Teacherage - Island Lake R.C. Day School

Dear Bishop Lajeunesse:

While not in a position to report on all items yet, I can advise with regard to furniture and to the rough lumber.

Purchase orders are now being prepared by the Departmental Purchasing Agent for the furniture requisitioned, with the exception of the following articles, which we do not supply for Indian day school teachers:

- Blankets,
- Sheets,
- Comforters.

While we do provide furniture for our school teachers, you will appreciate the fact that we cannot supply personal items such as those listed above.

With regard to the shingles and rough lumber, I have just received an airmail letter from Mr. Hughes, reading as follows:

"For a building of this type I would not recommend Island Lake Mill shingles.

"With reference to the lumber order I would state that we have the following rough lumber on hand at the..."
Department's Island Lake mill and have started a logging operation from which we hope to realize 300,000 feet:

| Size       | Quantity |
|------------|----------|
| 2 x 6      | 5,290    |
| 2 x 8      | 4,274    |
| 2 x 4      | 6,702    |
| 1" Rough Lbr.| 19,637   |

"This lumber is sawn to standard and will be pretty well seasoned by the time your building program is started. I presume that the carpenters will prefer a dimension lumber surfaced at least 2 sides and will require a quantity of shiplap from our rough 1" stock. This can be done provided the planer we have requisitioned is supplied. Might I suggest that you talk this matter over with Mr. Davis who I understand is in Ottawa until the end of the month.

"I would like to have at least a portion of this lumber order for our mill but unless our planer is being supplied in time to go in by tractor this winter - then the sawmill at the R.C. Mission will be your best source of supply."

I expect to see Mr. Davis tomorrow and will then be able to advise you whether a planer will be sent in to the Department's Island Lake mill.

I presume that you have a planer at the Island Lake R. C. Mission Mill.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

On October 16th 1948 I wrote the Department with regard to cement which was purchased from the J.H. Ashdown Hardware Co Ltd., Winnipeg, payment being covered by this Agency's voucher #975.

As mentioned in this letter, these supplies were intended for use in construction of the Jack River C of E Teacherage which had been completed the year previous. I suggested that this cement could be used in construction of basement for teacherage to be built at Island Lake R.C. Indian Day School this coming spring. If this cement is not used within the next six months it will be destroyed due to atmospheric conditions. Mr Stevenson will be making his trip to Norway House by tractor very shortly and could take this cement into Island Lake.

Also at Island Lake at the present time there are 375 bags of cement which belong to the Department, these being made up of cement shipped in for construction of basement for Assistant Agent's house which the department considered building several years ago and surplus left over re construction of Island Lake U.C. Indian Day School & Teacherage. Officials from the Provincial Government visited Island Lake recently and wanted to know if the Department would be willing to dispose of 270 bags of this cement as they are constructing a Game Guardian's residence there this year. They would have to know immediately whether the Department would sell as they would otherwise bring same in by Tractor Freight. Of this 375 bags of cement, at least 300 are useable, the balance having to be written off as destroyed.

Kindly advise by wire as to whether you wish to have cement shipped to Island Lake and if you wish to dispose of cement to provincial government.

F.M. Hughes, As Supt, Indian Agency.

Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Purchase Order 37890 was issued to T. Eaton Company some months ago for furnishings for the Island Lake R.C. School. - 1 kitchen set, 1 table and 8 chairs

- 1 dishpan

Re: Teacherage for Island Lake D.S.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

As work will soon begin on the construction of the Island Lake teacherage, Rev. Brother Boucher who will be in charge of its construction would like to know how much he should pay the Indians who will be employed as laborers on this job.

I have written to him today asking him to get in touch with Mr. Stevenson of Garden Hill to find out how much the latter has paid the Indians for the work they did during the winter for the Department and to use that as a guide for the wages which himself will be paying. I also told him to follow Mr. Stevenson's advice in this matter so that there will be no difficulty between the Mission and the Indians regarding these wages.

The payment of wages offers another difficulty which should be faced immediately and arrangements made to avoid any inconvenience to the Indians themselves. Island Lake is 300 Miles from here. There is no Bank or facilities for cashing checks. Therefore the money used to pay wages should be forwarded in kind. Your Mr. Stevenson who has handled money for wages should be able to give you the necessary advice in this matter.

Brother Boucher will be very busy on the construction itself and we believe he should not be asked
to keep books or to do more than keep the time of the Indians.

Yours very truly,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

I am in receipt of a copy of Department Letter 51775 of May 2nd to the most reverend M Lajeunesse, O.M.I., signed by Mr Neary re construction of Island Lake R.C. Indian Day School Teacherage.

With reference to the third paragraph in which it is stated that arrangements are being made for an accountable advance for the payment of Labour may I make the following suggestion. I am reasonably sure that arrangements can be made through the Hudson's Bay Company at Island Lake to pay cash to the workmen and forward invoices to this office monthly, supported by signed Labor Returns. My reasons for suggesting this procedure are that the Indians will require weekly pay. There are no banking facilities in Island Lake, Mr Stevenson lives some 10 miles from the Maria Portage area and weather conditions will no doubt prevent him from going to Maria Portage on pay day several times during the construction of the building. If satisfactory to the Department I would suggest that Brother E Boucher prepare the necessary paylists for the Indian workmen and submit them weekly to the Hudson's Bay Company who will get the required signatures as the Indians are paid and invoice this office every month. If these arrangements can be made for payment of Indian Labor I presume it would be in order to forward monthly vouchers covering Brother Boucher's wages in place of him being paid by the Hudson's Bay.

St. Peter's, Dynevor, Man.
Jan. 3rd 1910.

His Grace, the Primate,
Your Grace,

I find that it is almost impossible for me to leave St. Peter's just at this time. I am not over my vino season yet, as I have still two vinos here. I would also have to prepare beforehand before I could leave here without leaving my housekeeper in discomfort. I will have to leave a good supply of wood etc., and to arrange other details. But any time after the next two weeks provided your grace gives me ample notice beforehand, I shall be ready to make the trip to Fisher River and Jack Head.

Should your grace think it necessary that I should as your grace may not be quite clear about the affair at Jack Head, I wish to submit the following facts:

(1) Ever since 1905, when I had occasion to rebuild the Mission house at J.H. the Councillor, Geo. Harvey, has borne ill will towards me, owing to some supposed slight to his dignity and authority as Councillor. He then tried in every way to place obstacles in the way of my successfully carrying on the work, and also forced me to move the chapel from his land to a site near the mission house.
(2) He, as Councillor, expected me to pay tribute to him for the privilege of ministering to his people and on his Reserve, which I think did not think it right to do.

(3) The Councillor also tried to get me to make a compromise with him in the work viz. that I should not antagonize Christianity and Heathenism, so that I should not proselytise, which I could not do.

(4) I did my best to put an end to the heathen customs and illegal dances, by teaching the Christian Indians that they were wrong. These the Councillor feared, being the head of the heathen, and they were the chief means of his support.

(5) When I was going out last summer to J. H., I was met with the message that I was not wanted out there, and that the Councillor had vowed to drive me out.

From this you may see the reason of the Councillor's enmity.

He employed his strongest weapon—Slander—when he reported me to the Indian Agent as being immoral, and his motive was to prevent me returning to Jack Head.

He has repeatedly declared that he was satisfied with catechists and did not want an ordained man, as catechists could not proselytise, and could not interfere with heathenism to any extent.
The Councillor never had charge that he could bring against me, till this affair gave him an opportunity to charge something definite against me.

In this affair, the charge was not immorality. John Davies, a brother of the Councillor, instigated by his wife, endeavored to force me to marry his daughter. He claimed that I had asked him for his daughter, while as a matter of fact, it was they who were so anxious that I should become their son-in-law that they asked me on two occasions to make their daughter my wife. The parents, to prove that I was in love with their daughter and that I had asked for her, tried to show that I kept company with the girl, or paid court to her. I wrote and conducted my own defense, with the parents and five or six prominent heathen endeavoring to convict me of immorality with the girl. The witness called testified against the parents, as in every case they were falsely quoted. Not one of the alleged dealings with the girl were established. Even the chief witness, the girl herself denied that I had any dealings with her, or had ever asked for her, and she gave this testimony in the face of threatening and commands. My accusers, the parents and the heathen declared that she was shielding me.

Two men from Fisher River Reserve were called as witnesses of my carrying-on at Fisher River. But these also
were falsely quoted, as I subsequently obtained a written testimony of one in the presence of Mr. Stevens, the clergyman at Fisher River, declaring that he had never said a word to the detriment of my character, and that he knew nothing to defame my character. The other man gave the same testimony to Mr. Stevens.

At the end of the trial before the band of the Reserve, there was nothing established against my character; on the contrary, my character was completely vindicated. "Thus the purest things are saved." They were at the meeting some, viz., the father of the girl and the parents who believed I was guilty, and that the girl was shielding me. I attended the meeting of the band because I felt it was in the interest of my work to face the charge at once and show up the lie.

Two or three weeks after this trial, I kept in one girl during recess because she had not done her work. And though, knowing these people thoroughly, I took the precaution to have the sister of the girl in the room with her, and I went out for the ten minutes of recess with the other children, yet this act was construed by the Councilor as one of immorality on my part. This was the chief foundation of the charge against me.

They claim in the report against me that I had to file Jack Head, while as a matter of fact, my
departure at the beginning of May had long before been arranged with the Indian Commissioner and with your Grace for the necessities of my work.

They claim also in the report that the two councillors at Fisher River can testify as to my immoral life at Fisher River. Here is another weak point in their charge, for these men can testify that I conducted myself always as befitted my calling.

Mr. Stevens at Fisher River, Mr. Hart at Jack Head, and Mr. John Wheeler of St. Louis, Miss., can testify as to the purity of my conduct. When at Fisher River I stayed with Mr. Stevens, while Mr. Hart and Mr. Wheeler, an A.B. brother, were at Jack Head during the troubles in question.

I do not fear but would welcome investigation into my past life, as a school boy at the Battleford Industrial School I lived blamelessly as Rev. E. Matheson can readily testify. Seven months I was at St. Paul's Middle Church, where I was known to J. G. Dagg. I was two years at Lac Steil, as a teacher, and there also there was nothing to stain my character, and your Grace knows my character during the six years of my College course, in which I can confidently claim that I never gave you cause to suspect the purity of my life. Four years, or nearly so, was I at Jack Head, and there was never said anything to the detriment of my character.
All I had stirred up the enmity of Councillor Travers.

The Jack Head Indians are a class by themselves. They wish to cling to their heathenism, their feasts and illegal dances, and because an ordained man is a menace to the interests of their head men, they will resort to the most devilish means to drive out the clergyman. No clergyman, however pure his life, and however unblameable he may have been, who has laboured at Jack Head, has ever left the place without some slander attached to his name. But in every case these slanders were built on lies and were created by despicable machinations.

Your Grace will believe me when I say that I took my vows for the Priesthood in all sincerity, with a due sense of their importance and from a conviction that my life has been such as not to debar me from assuming those vows. And I wish to declare, as far as my witness, that I am not guilty of the charge brought against me by the Councillor of Jack Head.

If your Grace think it will do any good, I wish you would forward this to the authorities at Ottawa, and if they are not satisfied, I desire them to allow me to accompany Mr. Swiford to Fisher River and Jack Head, to investigate the charge.

Sincerely yours,

Louis Laronde.
Dear Mr. McLennan,

I wish to inform you that I have seen Rev. L. Laronde in regard to the charges which have been made against him by the Councillor at Jack Head through the Indian Agent in that district. He denies all the charges and protests stoutly his innocence and declares that he has never been guilty even of the slightest indiscretion. I am perfectly satisfied with the truth of his statements. He is the last man whom I would suspect of any immoral conduct. His life during his School and College course has been scrupulously clean in every respect. When I sent for him the other day and placed the charges before him he at once suggested that he should accompany one of your inspectors and subject himself to a thorough investigation before the Indians. I thought that this would be a good plan and at once telephoned to Mr. Swinford in order to ascertain whether he could arrange for carrying it out. He replied that he was starting for Fisher River the next but would not be able to go on to Jack Head. For the complete vindication of Laronde's character and for the sake of the work, I would like to see the investigation take place, for no man whom we have ever sent to Jack Head has escaped from the vilest slanders against his character. I remember the case of an excellent fellow named Bartlett whom I sent out there. He returned within two or three weeks declaring that the place was too vile for him to live in, adding that no matter how scrupulous his conduct might be he would be branded as an adulterer. Mr. Laronde's experience has been...
the same only he had apparently faced the charges before the Indians and defied them to prove them. He never fled from the place as is charged. I removed him because I wanted him for a more important post and he was very reluctant to leave and at first refused on the ground that he had brought the work at Jack Head to a point when it would be a serious set back to abandon it or give it into the hands of a new man who did not understand local conditions. It was only under pressure from me that he was induced to leave Jack Head and accept Dynevor. I enclose a letter which I received from Mr. Laroche this morning.

Yours very truly

J.D. McLean, Esq.,
Secy. Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Several years ago the Church of England had a teacher and a Catechist at Jack Head, the Government paying part of the salary and the Church supplementing the grant. Though we had some specially good men there the work was so discouraging and the Indians so troublesome that on the advice of the Superintendent of Missions, I withdrew from the work. Both the Superintendent and the Missionary advised me to close down the work and leave it closed until the Band would ask that it be resumed. A message has now come to me from the Band pleading that a teacher be sent. We have a good house there, a fair Church and I am told that there is a school-house which is considerably out of repair. I wish to ascertain whether the Department will sanction the appointment of a teacher and if I secure a good man what salary the Department would offer. In view of the history of the place in the past it would be prudent to send a married man rather than a single one.

I hope you are keeping in view the matter of the Fairford school and that you will give me a considerable period of notice if you wish me to accompany the person you send to deal with the matter. I had hoped to go

Dear Sir,

On my recent visit to Jackhead reserve, I took the opportunity of visiting the day school on that reserve while the classes were in session. When you consider that nine months ago not a child on the reserve could speak a word of English and today they can read or at least pronounce all the words in the second reader up to the fiftieth lesson, as well as count all Indian children have a habit of coming to a full stop after each word and the teachers tell me that it is hard to break them of it. This school is also doing well in arithmetic and writing. The boys and girls between the age of six and ten are making more progress than the older ones. The teacher Mr. Joseph Everett, who is a full blooded Indian seems to be possessed of an uncommon amount of patience, and has good influence upon the children, and the older people upon the reserve.

I find this building badly in need of repairs I would recommend a new floor and a new front door, also four rolls of patent roofing for the South side of the building, as the North side was covered with the same material last summer. The suggestion was made to us that the teacher now at Jackhead and his wife would be very valuable at Brokenhead, in the encouragement of garden operations and in the supervision of agricultural operations, generally. I do hope, though, that we shall have the active cooperation of all missionaries in the promotion of our programme. Dear Sir,

I took over here last October as Teacher, Anglican Church Lay Reader, and as Medical Dispenser. I have an housekeeper and non-official helper, my 18 yr old daughter, Miss Audrey Jeffery. We also the only whites on this River. This is my first experience in work of this nature.

Along the Jackhead river, a small stream emptying into Jackhead Bay, a long shallow bay dotted with reefs & boulders, an indentation of Sialis Bay proper, on West shore Lake Winnipeg about 15 Mi North & Northeast. There is no post mail service, nor any regular transportation. Personal arrangements are made with individual Indians in these respects. Only sailing ships are the only craft that navigate in and around the River. No power boats come in if they can avoid it, and if they do come in, invariably get out of the bay before dark, as very poor anchorage, and a low N.E. storm would very likely pile up the boat on the rocks or shallows. There is consequently very little contact with outsiders.

Population:

About 110 all told; men women and children. Tribal origin & speech Salteaux. Practically none of the grandparents or grandmothers speak.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6236, file 518-1, part 1)
any English; many of the fathers and mothers do not either. Some of the younger men who go out working—principally with the Icelandic fishing outfits—speak some English, but none fluently and very few can read it with in English. The children starting school speak only Icelandic. All depend on subsistence, and I believe judge that about 80% of the Band's living is derived from this industry. Scarcity of fuel has been a serious handicap to a promising point. Food and clothing are ever present problems, preserving and insuperable. Living standards are of a primitive order.

Agriculture:

No attempt is made to farm. Some families have very small garden plots 25x30 ft. mostly. In these they plant a few potatoes, when seed can be had. No fertilizing has been done, they are often late in their cultivation, weeding etc., and results are often poor. No work of any kind has been done for three seasons on the School & Mission Cottage gardens. I find that "quick lime" has taken quite hold, but I have turned the land over, gathered manure, and purpose to plant potatoes & a few small seeds and grain for a start. Land is generally light and sandy. Easily cultivated but requires constant fertilizers and plenty of rain.

A few cattle about 15 head run on the Reserve, one cow, bull aged 7 or 8, bull about 3 years old. Cattle thin, good size & condition, run out all summer and most of the winter. There are no horses on the reserve. All hay is made and harvested by hand. Two oxen have been helping to work.

Dear Miss Skaftfeld:

Jackhead Indian Day School

As you are aware, you were classified as a Welfare teacher while you were employed at the Kitwancool Indian Day School. In a salary letter sent to you at that school on August 13, 1948, you were advised that your salary would be for twelve months' service.

Yet without any notification to the Department or its officials, you left the Kitwancool school in July in order to attend summer school at the University of Manitoba.

The regulations concerning Welfare teachers printed in the School bulletin clearly define the number of days annual holidays to which Welfare teachers are entitled. I presume that you received your cheques while you were attending the University of Manitoba and feel that an explanation should be forwarded here concerning this matter.

To summarize, you left your Welfare position without permission during the months of July and August and received a salary during these months when you were not engaged in teaching or welfare activities for the Department.

Yours sincerely,

Ottawa, August 17, 1932.

Sir:

I have to inform you that His Grace the Archbishop of Rupert's Land has nominated the services of Mrs. Catherine Ruth McKenzie for the position as teacher and dispenser at the Jack Head Indian Day School. The Department is approving of Mrs. McKenzie's appointment, with salary at the rate of $90 per teaching month, less 10% for the current fiscal year, for her services as teacher. If she carries out the duties of dispenser, $50 per annum, less 10% for the present fiscal year, will be allowed her.

Mrs. McKenzie's husband, if unable to obtain employment elsewhere, will live with her at Jack Head. His Grace informs the Department that he has had a report from you regarding conditions at Jack Head and that you advised that a married couple be appointed. I may add, however, that it is not the general practice of the Department to appoint a married teacher when there are no duties for which the services of the husband could be engaged.

His Grace is being requested to notify Mrs. McKenzie of her appointment and to arrange with her to begin duties on or about September first, next. I would request that you give her every assistance you can in her work.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

G. H. Lavender, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hodgson,
Man.
